be.', 'if you need a hat to be 10 inches high, cast on enough stitches to reach 10 inches.', 'knit the fabric as long as you want the hat to be around (circumference).', 'knit until the piece reaches the desired length around the head, then bind off.', 'bind off the fabric but leave a long tail of yarn instead of cutting it very close.', 'after binding off, pull the tail through the last stitch to finish the bind off completely.', 'use a yarn needle to sew the cast-on edge to the bind-off edge.', 'identify the cast-on edge (where you started) and the cast-off edge (where you stopped knitting) before seaming.', 'align the cast-on edge with the cast-off edge and sew them together so the fabric becomes a tube.', 'pick up the small ladder-like spaces between bind-off stitches with the yarn needle when seaming the bind-off edge.', 'secure the corner first when starting the seam to hold the edges together.', 'pick up both sides (both legs) of matching stitches and pull the yarn through to join them when seaming.', 'use a whip stitch (going back and forth) to sew up the side of the fabric and close the tube.', 'pick up both legs of each stitch when seaming to create a neat, secure seam.', 'finish the starting tail stitch and then stitch up one end of the tube to close the top and form the hat shape.', 'when you pull the closing stitches tight the closed end will bunch and form the top of the hat.', 'after pulling the top closed tight, pass the needle through the closure again to add extra tightening if needed.', 'weave in the loose yarn ends after closing the top of the hat.', 'turn the hat right side out after weaving in ends to finish.', 'fold it in half now.', 'fold over the top half of the paper.', 'fold the paper in half again to make a guide down the middle ### INPUTS
Information 1: Paint the hats with the preschool class tomorrow.
Surrounding context (tutorial excerpt): ```to go let's see okay so we're done with the hats the only thing left to do is to paint them and make them colorful so tomorrow we're going to paint them with their preschool class and it should be a lot of fun right okay so see you```
Information 2: Estimate slit length; around three inches (about seven centimeters) is fine.
Surrounding context (tutorial excerpt): ```centimeters or eight inches or something like that eight and a half inches it's a square so both sides are the same length okay then the top of my square I cut two slits again I just kind of estimating it's not being a very good in the crafter so it's like three inches about or seven centimeters obviously it's not super duper important how big it is because I just asked me to indicate myself anyways okay so you have your three slits cut```
Information 3: Fold the top sheet at the bottom open end upward and over the flaps you folded down.
Surrounding context (tutorial excerpt): ```the Hat experiment to find the right sized paper step 2 arranged the folded paper in front of you so that the fold is at the top and the opening is at the bottom step 3 fold the two top corners to the middle of the paper so that you form a point on top step 4 fold the top sheet at the bottom open end upward and over the flaps you folded down double the fold and then turn the hat over to fold the other side step 5 punch holes in either side of the hat thread an elastic cord through the holes```

| Type | Example Titles | Example Labels | Example Distinction |

| How | Method / Tool used | Manual / Automated | Using different approaches or tools |

1. Identify at least one aspect of a task context that would assign DIFFERENT segment labels to the pieces. You can list multiple aspects if you can, but make sure they are orthogonal (i.e., do not overlap with respect to type).
2. Classify which type of aspect it belongs to ("when", "why", "where", "what", or "how").
3. Briefly justify the choice of the aspect and the type of segmentation.
4. Describe how the task can be segmented or divided along this aspect.  
5. Provide brief "guidelines" that explain how to identify segment boundaries or assign labels based on the transcript of a tutorial. 
6. Provide a few examples of "segment labels".

### ANNOTATION GUIDELINES
- Use only the transcript text to infer the distinction.
- Keep aspect titles short, but easily interpretable (max. 2-3 words).
- Keep example segment labels short, but easily interpretable (max. 2-3 words).

You are a helpful assistant who can reliably and precisely describe task contexts where pieces of information apply.
ROLE: user

You are given information pieces from tutorial videos about How to Make a Paper Hat. Identify a set of aspects of a task context (a particular temporal segmentation) that would assign DIFFERENT segment labels to the pieces.

### INPUTS
Information 1: Put each partygoer's name on their hat using stickers when making hats for multiple kids.
Surrounding context (tutorial excerpt): ```you decorate it now I suggest using stickers as well especially letter stickers and if you were having a birthday party and there were a bunch of different kids you could put their names on them which is kind of cool and certain stickers will add your own unique flair to your hat I think this is great for birthday parties and if I ever have kids it's totally something I would do it has some of these steampunk ears that I'm going to```
Information 2: The fold does not have to be very accurate.
Surrounding context (tutorial excerpt): ```all right okay a nother paper hell - now we're going to be making a paper hat and do so you will first need to fold the paper in half doesn't have to be too accurate fold it in half now this bit you have to fold over the top half okay```
Information 3: Suggestion: Before following the video, consider watching the whole video first.
Surrounding context (tutorial excerpt): ```guys today I'm going to be showing you how to make a paper hat well I wouldn't before watch this video I would say if you're going to do this as I as I go along you might want to take a bigger piece of paper on other than this because then I was a little bigger mahat if you use this piece of paper it's going to make a little kind of thing```

| Where | Environment | Field / Lab | Different physical or digital settings |
| What | Object of focus | Hardware / Software | Working on different components |
| How | Method / Tool used | Manual / Automated | Using different approaches or tools |

You are given information pieces from tutorial videos about How to Make a Paper Hat. Identify a set of aspects of a task context (a particular temporal segmentation) that would assign DIFFERENT segment labels to the pieces.

### INPUTS
Information 1: Get a newspaper.
Surrounding context (tutorial excerpt): ```hate you today i teach you how to make a paper hat out of a newspaper so here we go there's five steps to do here we go step one you get your shiny newspaper as so my newspaper is conex East garland news how interesting you get a newspaper and you fold in her which is pretty easy because newspapers for like that enemies```
Information 2: You can use the long tail you left or a separate piece of yarn to seam the hat.
Surrounding context (tutorial excerpt): ```going to do we're going to sew the cast on edge to the cast-off edge the bind off and the bind on we're going to sew those together and you're going to end up with this two looking thing okay like that so you want to take your really long tail that you left you also can use another piece of yarn to do this you know just if you want you can use a different size of yarn I prefer to use the yarn that I used to sew the Hat so that way it doesn't show if it gets pulled apart okay so here we are we have our yarn```
Information 3: Have a meal apron to cover the child because the activity can get messy.
Surrounding context (tutorial excerpt): ```don't have to be approximate that's only approximate you don't have to do it exactly the other thing you'll need is a pot of PVA glue which has some water in so it's running and you'll need a paintbrush and your meal apron that will cover your child because it can get messy so what I recommend is that you get your child to cover an area of the balloon with glue and I'll show you that it should just run on the balloon quite```

| Type | Example Titles | Example Labels | Example Distinction |

| Where | Environment | Field / Lab | Different physical or digital settings |
| What | Object of focus | Hardware / Software | Working on different components |
| How | Method / Tool used | Manual / Automated | Using different approaches or tools |

### PROCEDURE
1. Identify at least one aspect of a task context that would assign DIFFERENT segment labels to the pieces. You can list multiple aspects if you can, but make sure they are orthogonal (i.e., do not overlap with respect to type).
2. Classify which type of aspect it belongs to ("when", "why", "where", "what", or "how").
3. Briefly justify the choice of the aspect and the type of segmentation.
4. Describe how the task can be segmented or divided along this aspect.  
5. Provide brief "guidelines" that explain how to identify segment boundaries or assign labels based on the transcript of a tutorial. 
6. Provide a few examples of "segment labels".

### ANNOTATION GUIDELINES
- Use only the transcript text to infer the distinction.
- Keep aspect titles short, but easily interpretable (max. 2-3 words).
- Keep example segment labels short, but easily interpretable (max. 2-3 words).

### INPUTS
Information 1: The paper hat is suitable for parties.
Surrounding context (tutorial excerpt): ```and there you have your paper hat so now i'm going to get my sister change to mark the hat for you and now this piece of crud turns into a divine hash for all parties give us a spin on his vine to vine and now probably small headed people we have the manager version of the paper hat give us a spin or which is simply divine so now the next time you go to buy a hash don't bother I make```
Information 2: The instructor lives in Australia but is originally from the northeastern United States.
Surrounding context (tutorial excerpt): ```that is meant for all of those people who have been dealing with snow days and born children as a result of the snow days now as you probably know I live in Australia but I am from the northeastern part of the United States and boy oh boy have you guys had some weather recently whoa Facebook was literally blowing up with oh no not another snow day we're gonna be going to school in July at this rate right oh it's horrible but if```
Information 3: A square's both sides are the same length.
Surrounding context (tutorial excerpt): ```square square my square is I don't know I just kind of estimated 21 and a half centimeters or eight inches or something like that eight and a half inches it's a square so both sides are the same length okay then the top of my square I cut two slits again I just kind of estimating it's not being a very good in the crafter so it's like three inches about or seven```


### POSSIBLE TYPES OF ASPECTS:
| Type | Example Titles | Example Labels | Example Distinction |
|------|----------------|----------------|----------------------|
| When | Stage of process | Setup / Execution | Different steps in time |
| Why | Purpose / Subgoal | Collect Data / Analyze Data | Different goals or intentions |
| Where | Environment | Field / Lab | Different physical or digital settings |
| What | Object of focus | Hardware / Software | Working on different components |
| How | Method / Tool used | Manual / Automated | Using different approaches or tools |

### PROCEDURE
1. Identify at least one aspect of a task context that would assign DIFFERENT segment labels to the pieces. You can list multiple aspects if you can, but make sure they are orthogonal (i.e., do not overlap with respect to type).
2. Classify which type of aspect it belongs to ("when", "why", "where", "what", or "how").
3. Briefly justify the choice of the aspect and the type of segmentation.
4. Describe how the task can be segmented or divided along this aspect.  
5. Provide brief "guidelines" that explain how to identify segment boundaries or assign labels based on the transcript of a tutorial. 
6. Provide a few examples of "segment labels".

### ANNOTATION GUIDELINES
- Use only the transcript text to infer the distinction.
- Keep aspect titles short, but easily interpretable (max. 2-3 words).
- Keep example segment labels short, but easily interpretable (max. 2-3 words).

MESSAGES: ROLE: system
You are a helpful assistant who can reliably and precisely describe task contexts where pieces of information apply.
ROLE: user

You are analyzing aspects of a task context (a particular temporal segmentation) for `How to Make a Paper Hat`/

### INPUTS
- Aspects of a task context, each labeled with an ID in square brackets (e.g., "[F1] ..."): [F1] (when) Stage (Plural: Stages) -- Divide the tutorial into ordered temporal steps from setup/preparation, through execution of construction actions, to finishing/aftercare steps. Each transcript piece is labeled by which step in the overall process it belongs to (e.g., Preparation, Construction, Finishing).
Guidelines for defining labels: ```
- Label a segment as Preparation if the speaker talks about future plans, scheduling, gathering materials, or orienting participants (mentions 'tomorrow', 'we're going to', or class/participants).
- Label as Construction when the speaker describes concrete making actions (cutting, folding, measuring, punching, threading) and gives measurements or exact manipulation instructions.
- Label as Finishing if the speaker describes final touches, decorating, or completion remarks (painting, coloring, 'we're done', or concluding statements).
- Assign boundaries when the transcript shifts from describing what will happen or is prepared for (Preparation) into step-by-step physical operations (Construction), and finally into decoration/closure (Finishing).
```
Example labels: ```
[S1] Preparation
Definition: Planning, scheduling, or arranging participants/materials before making begins.
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
No examples contents and context are available.
```
[S2] Construction
Definition: Active building steps: cutting, folding, measuring, assembling the hat.

- If the text gives measurements or instructions about cuts/slits in the paper, label as 'Slit/Cut'.
- If the text instructs folding of sheets, flaps, or assembling layers, label as 'Fold/Flap'.

- Label as Measure/Estimate when the speaker provides numerical guidance, lengths, or indicates approximation (mentions inches, centimeters, 'about').
- Label as Manipulate when the speaker gives step-by-step physical instructions (fold, turn, punch, thread).
- Boundaries occur where the dominant verb category changes from planning to measuring to hands-on manipulation.

```

### GOAL
Combine the given aspects of a task context to get a set of aspects of a task context that are orthogonal (the segmentation wrt one aspect does not determine the segmentation wrt another aspect), single-slot (the segmentation title and labels are short and easily interpretable), and cover all initial aspects of a task context.

### POSSIBLE TYPES OF ASPECTS:
| Type | Example Titles | Example Labels | Example Distinction |
|------|----------------|----------------|----------------------|
| When | Stage of process | Setup / Execution | Different steps in time |
| Why | Purpose / Subgoal | Collect Data / Analyze Data | Different goals or intentions |
| Where | Environment | Field / Lab | Different physical or digital settings |
| What | Object of focus | Hardware / Software | Working on different components |
| How | Method / Tool used | Manual / Automated | Using different approaches or tools |

### PROCEDURE
Iterate until stable:
1) Check for orthogonality:
    - Redefine or replace non-orthogonal pairs with independent aspects of a task context.  
    - Example (WRONG: not independent):  
        - [F3] Physical settings
        - [F4] Settings
        - Settings are more general than physical settings, so can focus on one of the two.
    - Example (CORRECT: independent redesign):  
        - [F4] Settings
2) Check for single-slot:
    - Rephrase aspects of a task context so that segmentation title and labels fit in max. 3 words, but are easily interpretable.
    - Example (WRONG: too long):  
        - [F5] Task phase segmentation
    - Example (CORRECT: single-slot):  
        - [F5] Phases
4) Check for coverage:
    - Ensure the new set preserves all the meaning of the original aspects of a task context.

### EXIT CONDITION
The final aspect set is smallest (i.e., has the fewest number of aspects), orthogonal, single-slot, and fully covers the initial aspects.

### GOAL
Return an updated list of segment labels for temporal segmentation of the tutorial based on Stages (including existing and any new ones needed to cover the given transcript), each with 1-2 concrete examples grounded in the given transcript (or reused from the existing labels).

### GUIDELINES FOR SEGMENTATION:
- Label as Preparation when the speaker talks about gathering materials, sizing, planning, scheduling, or giving high-level orientation before hands-on steps.
- Label as Construction when the dominant content is concrete building actions (folding, cutting, measuring, punching, assembling) and step-by-step instructions.
- Label as Finishing when the content covers decorating, drying, trimming, presentation, or wrap-up/closing comments.
- Assign a boundary at the moment the transcript shifts from describing what will be done (Preparation) into concrete manipulation steps (Construction), and again when it shifts from core construction to decoration/closure (Finishing).

### GENERAL NORMALIZATION RULES (apply in addition to the above):
- Merge synonyms/variants into one segment label; keep the existing labels as the canonical form when applicable.
- Use concise, unambiguous phrasing; avoid brand-specific or overly narrow wording unless essential to task fidelity.
- Only add a new segment label if the transcript contains a segment that is not covered by any existing segment label.

### PROCEDURE
1) Segment the transcript temporally following the segmentation guidelines.
2) For each segment:
    - Try to map it to an existing segment label.
    - If no existing segment label fits, propose a new segment label following the guidelines.
3) For every segment label in the final list (existing or new):
    - Provide 1-2 representative examples.
    - Each example must include:
        - content (the exact minimal excerpt that would be labeled as the segment label)
        - context (around 10-20 words surrounding the content and the content itself)
    - If a segment label is not evidenced in the given transcript, reuse one example from the existing list if available.

### OUTPUT
Return a list of segment labels. Each segment label should have the following fields:
- id: id of the segment label
- label: short text less than 2-3 words
- definition: elaboration of what the segment label means
- examples: 1-2 short representative content and context that would be labeled as the segment label

NOTES
- Ground everything in the provided inputs; no external knowledge or speculation.
- Do not create duplicate or overlapping segment labels.
- Keep examples short and specific; avoid paraphrasing for the 'content' field.

### GUIDELINES FOR SEGMENTATION:
- Label as Preparation when the speaker talks about gathering materials, sizing, planning, scheduling, or giving high-level orientation before hands-on steps.
- Label as Construction when the dominant content is concrete building actions (folding, cutting, measuring, punching, assembling) and step-by-step instructions.
- Label as Finishing when the content covers decorating, drying, trimming, presentation, or wrap-up/closing comments.
- Assign a boundary at the moment the transcript shifts from describing what will be done (Preparation) into concrete manipulation steps (Construction), and again when it shifts from core construction to decoration/closure (Finishing).

### GENERAL NORMALIZATION RULES (apply in addition to the above):
- Merge synonyms/variants into one segment label; keep the existing labels as the canonical form when applicable.
- Use concise, unambiguous phrasing; avoid brand-specific or overly narrow wording unless essential to task fidelity.
- Only add a new segment label if the transcript contains a segment that is not covered by any existing segment label.

### GOAL
Return an updated list of segment labels for temporal segmentation of the tutorial based on Stages (including existing and any new ones needed to cover the given transcript), each with 1-2 concrete examples grounded in the given transcript (or reused from the existing labels).

### GUIDELINES FOR SEGMENTATION:
- Label as Preparation when the speaker talks about gathering materials, sizing, planning, scheduling, or giving high-level orientation before hands-on steps.
- Label as Construction when the dominant content is concrete building actions (folding, cutting, measuring, punching, assembling) and step-by-step instructions.
- Label as Finishing when the content covers decorating, drying, trimming, presentation, or wrap-up/closing comments.
- Assign a boundary at the moment the transcript shifts from describing what will be done (Preparation) into concrete manipulation steps (Construction), and again when it shifts from core construction to decoration/closure (Finishing).

### GENERAL NORMALIZATION RULES (apply in addition to the above):
- Merge synonyms/variants into one segment label; keep the existing labels as the canonical form when applicable.
- Use concise, unambiguous phrasing; avoid brand-specific or overly narrow wording unless essential to task fidelity.
- Only add a new segment label if the transcript contains a segment that is not covered by any existing segment label.

### PROCEDURE
1) Segment the transcript temporally following the segmentation guidelines.
2) For each segment:
    - Try to map it to an existing segment label.
    - If no existing segment label fits, propose a new segment label following the guidelines.
3) For every segment label in the final list (existing or new):
    - Provide 1-2 representative examples.
    - Each example must include:
        - content (the exact minimal excerpt that would be labeled as the segment label)
        - context (around 10-20 words surrounding the content and the content itself)
    - If a segment label is not evidenced in the given transcript, reuse one example from the existing list if available.

### OUTPUT
Return a list of segment labels. Each segment label should have the following fields:
- id: id of the segment label
- label: short text less than 2-3 words
- definition: elaboration of what the segment label means
- examples: 1-2 short representative content and context that would be labeled as the segment label

NOTES
- Ground everything in the provided inputs; no external knowledge or speculation.
- Do not create duplicate or overlapping segment labels.
- Keep examples short and specific; avoid paraphrasing for the 'content' field.

### GOAL
Return an updated list of segment labels for temporal segmentation of the tutorial based on Stages (including existing and any new ones needed to cover the given transcript), each with 1-2 concrete examples grounded in the given transcript (or reused from the existing labels).

### GUIDELINES FOR SEGMENTATION:
- Label as Preparation when the speaker talks about gathering materials, sizing, planning, scheduling, or giving high-level orientation before hands-on steps.
- Label as Construction when the dominant content is concrete building actions (folding, cutting, measuring, punching, assembling) and step-by-step instructions.
- Label as Finishing when the content covers decorating, drying, trimming, presentation, or wrap-up/closing comments.
- Assign a boundary at the moment the transcript shifts from describing what will be done (Preparation) into concrete manipulation steps (Construction), and again when it shifts from core construction to decoration/closure (Finishing).

### GENERAL NORMALIZATION RULES (apply in addition to the above):
- Merge synonyms/variants into one segment label; keep the existing labels as the canonical form when applicable.
- Use concise, unambiguous phrasing; avoid brand-specific or overly narrow wording unless essential to task fidelity.
- Only add a new segment label if the transcript contains a segment that is not covered by any existing segment label.

### PROCEDURE
1) Segment the transcript temporally following the segmentation guidelines.
2) For each segment:
    - Try to map it to an existing segment label.
    - If no existing segment label fits, propose a new segment label following the guidelines.
3) For every segment label in the final list (existing or new):
    - Provide 1-2 representative examples.
    - Each example must include:
        - content (the exact minimal excerpt that would be labeled as the segment label)
        - context (around 10-20 words surrounding the content and the content itself)
    - If a segment label is not evidenced in the given transcript, reuse one example from the existing list if available.

### OUTPUT
Return a list of segment labels. Each segment label should have the following fields:
- id: id of the segment label
- label: short text less than 2-3 words
- definition: elaboration of what the segment label means
- examples: 1-2 short representative content and context that would be labeled as the segment label

NOTES
- Ground everything in the provided inputs; no external knowledge or speculation.
- Do not create duplicate or overlapping segment labels.
- Keep examples short and specific; avoid paraphrasing for the 'content' field.

```
[S3] Finishing

ROLE: user

You are discovering segment labels for temporal segmentation of a tutorial based on Stages (i.e., Divide the transcript into ordered temporal steps of the hat-making process. Assign each transcript piece to the stage it primarily describes: Preparation (planning, gathering materials, orientation), Construction (step-by-step physical building and folding), or Finishing (final touches, decoration, drying, closing remarks).).

### INPUTS
- Existing segment labels:
[S1] Preparation
Definition: Planning, gathering materials, sizing and orienting participants before making begins.
Examples (Contents and Context): ```

	- Context 1: 7 - 17 for this you're going to use some tissue paper a ruler a pencil some glue and some scissors I'm

	- Context 1: 45 - 49 now we're going to fold it into three and then we're going to cut off the top and the bottom so that there we have four
	- Content 2: now we're going to cut a triangle in the top followed by half a triangle
	- Context 2: 61 - 74 now we're going to cut a triangle in the top followed by half a triangle
```
[S3] Finishing
Definition: Final touches, decoration, presentation, or closing remarks after core construction is complete.
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
	- Content 1: thank you for watching
	- Context 1: 90 - 90 thank you for watching and if you'd like
	- Content 2: if you'd like me to show you how to make the cracker from the Hat then you'll find the link in the description below
	- Context 2: 90 - 102 thank you for watching and if you'd like me to show you how to make the cracker from the Hat then you'll find the link in the description below bye for now

### GOAL
Return an updated list of segment labels for temporal segmentation of the tutorial based on Stages (including existing and any new ones needed to cover the given transcript), each with 1-2 concrete examples grounded in the given transcript (or reused from the existing labels).

### GUIDELINES FOR SEGMENTATION:
- Label as Preparation when the speaker talks about gathering materials, sizing, planning, scheduling, or giving high-level orientation before hands-on steps.
- Label as Construction when the dominant content is concrete building actions (folding, cutting, measuring, punching, assembling) and step-by-step instructions.
- Label as Finishing when the content covers decorating, drying, trimming, presentation, or wrap-up/closing comments.
- Assign a boundary at the moment the transcript shifts from describing what will be done (Preparation) into concrete manipulation steps (Construction), and again when it shifts from core construction to decoration/closure (Finishing).

### GENERAL NORMALIZATION RULES (apply in addition to the above):
- Merge synonyms/variants into one segment label; keep the existing labels as the canonical form when applicable.
- Use concise, unambiguous phrasing; avoid brand-specific or overly narrow wording unless essential to task fidelity.
- Only add a new segment label if the transcript contains a segment that is not covered by any existing segment label.

### PROCEDURE
1) Segment the transcript temporally following the segmentation guidelines.
2) For each segment:
    - Try to map it to an existing segment label.
    - If no existing segment label fits, propose a new segment label following the guidelines.
3) For every segment label in the final list (existing or new):
    - Provide 1-2 representative examples.
    - Each example must include:
        - content (the exact minimal excerpt that would be labeled as the segment label)
        - context (around 10-20 words surrounding the content and the content itself)
    - If a segment label is not evidenced in the given transcript, reuse one example from the existing list if available.

### OUTPUT
Return a list of segment labels. Each segment label should have the following fields:
- id: id of the segment label
- label: short text less than 2-3 words
- definition: elaboration of what the segment label means
- examples: 1-2 short representative content and context that would be labeled as the segment label

NOTES
- Ground everything in the provided inputs; no external knowledge or speculation.
- Do not create duplicate or overlapping segment labels.
- Keep examples short and specific; avoid paraphrasing for the 'content' field.

### GOAL
Return an updated list of segment labels for temporal segmentation of the tutorial based on Stages (including existing and any new ones needed to cover the given transcript), each with 1-2 concrete examples grounded in the given transcript (or reused from the existing labels).

### GUIDELINES FOR SEGMENTATION:
- Label as Preparation when the speaker talks about gathering materials, sizing, planning, scheduling, or giving high-level orientation before hands-on steps.
- Label as Construction when the dominant content is concrete building actions (folding, cutting, measuring, punching, assembling) and step-by-step instructions.
- Label as Finishing when the content covers decorating, drying, trimming, presentation, or wrap-up/closing comments.
- Assign a boundary at the moment the transcript shifts from describing what will be done (Preparation) into concrete manipulation steps (Construction), and again when it shifts from core construction to decoration/closure (Finishing).

### GENERAL NORMALIZATION RULES (apply in addition to the above):
- Merge synonyms/variants into one segment label; keep the existing labels as the canonical form when applicable.
- Use concise, unambiguous phrasing; avoid brand-specific or overly narrow wording unless essential to task fidelity.
- Only add a new segment label if the transcript contains a segment that is not covered by any existing segment label.

### PROCEDURE
1) Segment the transcript temporally following the segmentation guidelines.
2) For each segment:
    - Try to map it to an existing segment label.
    - If no existing segment label fits, propose a new segment label following the guidelines.
3) For every segment label in the final list (existing or new):
    - Provide 1-2 representative examples.
    - Each example must include:
        - content (the exact minimal excerpt that would be labeled as the segment label)
        - context (around 10-20 words surrounding the content and the content itself)
    - If a segment label is not evidenced in the given transcript, reuse one example from the existing list if available.

### OUTPUT
Return a list of segment labels. Each segment label should have the following fields:
- id: id of the segment label
- label: short text less than 2-3 words
- definition: elaboration of what the segment label means
- examples: 1-2 short representative content and context that would be labeled as the segment label

NOTES
- Ground everything in the provided inputs; no external knowledge or speculation.
- Do not create duplicate or overlapping segment labels.
- Keep examples short and specific; avoid paraphrasing for the 'content' field.

### GOAL
Return an updated list of segment labels for temporal segmentation of the tutorial based on Stages (including existing and any new ones needed to cover the given transcript), each with 1-2 concrete examples grounded in the given transcript (or reused from the existing labels).

### GUIDELINES FOR SEGMENTATION:
- Label as Preparation when the speaker talks about gathering materials, sizing, planning, scheduling, or giving high-level orientation before hands-on steps.
- Label as Construction when the dominant content is concrete building actions (folding, cutting, measuring, punching, assembling) and step-by-step instructions.
- Label as Finishing when the content covers decorating, drying, trimming, presentation, or wrap-up/closing comments.
- Assign a boundary at the moment the transcript shifts from describing what will be done (Preparation) into concrete manipulation steps (Construction), and again when it shifts from core construction to decoration/closure (Finishing).

### GENERAL NORMALIZATION RULES (apply in addition to the above):
- Merge synonyms/variants into one segment label; keep the existing labels as the canonical form when applicable.
- Use concise, unambiguous phrasing; avoid brand-specific or overly narrow wording unless essential to task fidelity.
- Only add a new segment label if the transcript contains a segment that is not covered by any existing segment label.

### PROCEDURE
1) Segment the transcript temporally following the segmentation guidelines.
2) For each segment:
    - Try to map it to an existing segment label.
    - If no existing segment label fits, propose a new segment label following the guidelines.
3) For every segment label in the final list (existing or new):
    - Provide 1-2 representative examples.
    - Each example must include:
        - content (the exact minimal excerpt that would be labeled as the segment label)
        - context (around 10-20 words surrounding the content and the content itself)
    - If a segment label is not evidenced in the given transcript, reuse one example from the existing list if available.

### OUTPUT
Return a list of segment labels. Each segment label should have the following fields:
- id: id of the segment label
- label: short text less than 2-3 words
- definition: elaboration of what the segment label means
- examples: 1-2 short representative content and context that would be labeled as the segment label

NOTES
- Ground everything in the provided inputs; no external knowledge or speculation.
- Do not create duplicate or overlapping segment labels.
- Keep examples short and specific; avoid paraphrasing for the 'content' field.

### GOAL
Return an updated list of segment labels for temporal segmentation of the tutorial based on Stages (including existing and any new ones needed to cover the given transcript), each with 1-2 concrete examples grounded in the given transcript (or reused from the existing labels).

### GUIDELINES FOR SEGMENTATION:
- Label as Preparation when the speaker talks about gathering materials, sizing, planning, scheduling, or giving high-level orientation before hands-on steps.
- Label as Construction when the dominant content is concrete building actions (folding, cutting, measuring, punching, assembling) and step-by-step instructions.
- Label as Finishing when the content covers decorating, drying, trimming, presentation, or wrap-up/closing comments.
- Assign a boundary at the moment the transcript shifts from describing what will be done (Preparation) into concrete manipulation steps (Construction), and again when it shifts from core construction to decoration/closure (Finishing).

### GENERAL NORMALIZATION RULES (apply in addition to the above):
- Merge synonyms/variants into one segment label; keep the existing labels as the canonical form when applicable.
- Use concise, unambiguous phrasing; avoid brand-specific or overly narrow wording unless essential to task fidelity.
- Only add a new segment label if the transcript contains a segment that is not covered by any existing segment label.

### PROCEDURE
1) Segment the transcript temporally following the segmentation guidelines.
2) For each segment:
    - Try to map it to an existing segment label.
    - If no existing segment label fits, propose a new segment label following the guidelines.
3) For every segment label in the final list (existing or new):
    - Provide 1-2 representative examples.
    - Each example must include:
        - content (the exact minimal excerpt that would be labeled as the segment label)
        - context (around 10-20 words surrounding the content and the content itself)
    - If a segment label is not evidenced in the given transcript, reuse one example from the existing list if available.

### OUTPUT
Return a list of segment labels. Each segment label should have the following fields:
- id: id of the segment label
- label: short text less than 2-3 words
- definition: elaboration of what the segment label means
- examples: 1-2 short representative content and context that would be labeled as the segment label

NOTES
- Ground everything in the provided inputs; no external knowledge or speculation.
- Do not create duplicate or overlapping segment labels.
- Keep examples short and specific; avoid paraphrasing for the 'content' field.

### GOAL
Return an updated list of segment labels for temporal segmentation of the tutorial based on Stages (including existing and any new ones needed to cover the given transcript), each with 1-2 concrete examples grounded in the given transcript (or reused from the existing labels).

### GUIDELINES FOR SEGMENTATION:
- Label as Preparation when the speaker talks about gathering materials, sizing, planning, scheduling, or giving high-level orientation before hands-on steps.
- Label as Construction when the dominant content is concrete building actions (folding, cutting, measuring, punching, assembling) and step-by-step instructions.
- Label as Finishing when the content covers decorating, drying, trimming, presentation, or wrap-up/closing comments.
- Assign a boundary at the moment the transcript shifts from describing what will be done (Preparation) into concrete manipulation steps (Construction), and again when it shifts from core construction to decoration/closure (Finishing).

### GENERAL NORMALIZATION RULES (apply in addition to the above):
- Merge synonyms/variants into one segment label; keep the existing labels as the canonical form when applicable.
- Use concise, unambiguous phrasing; avoid brand-specific or overly narrow wording unless essential to task fidelity.
- Only add a new segment label if the transcript contains a segment that is not covered by any existing segment label.

### PROCEDURE
1) Segment the transcript temporally following the segmentation guidelines.
2) For each segment:
    - Try to map it to an existing segment label.
    - If no existing segment label fits, propose a new segment label following the guidelines.
3) For every segment label in the final list (existing or new):
    - Provide 1-2 representative examples.
    - Each example must include:
        - content (the exact minimal excerpt that would be labeled as the segment label)
        - context (around 10-20 words surrounding the content and the content itself)
    - If a segment label is not evidenced in the given transcript, reuse one example from the existing list if available.

### OUTPUT
Return a list of segment labels. Each segment label should have the following fields:
- id: id of the segment label
- label: short text less than 2-3 words
- definition: elaboration of what the segment label means
- examples: 1-2 short representative content and context that would be labeled as the segment label

NOTES
- Ground everything in the provided inputs; no external knowledge or speculation.
- Do not create duplicate or overlapping segment labels.
- Keep examples short and specific; avoid paraphrasing for the 'content' field.

### GUIDELINES FOR SEGMENTATION:
- Label as Preparation when the speaker talks about gathering materials, sizing, planning, scheduling, or giving high-level orientation before hands-on steps.
- Label as Construction when the dominant content is concrete building actions (folding, cutting, measuring, punching, assembling) and step-by-step instructions.
- Label as Finishing when the content covers decorating, drying, trimming, presentation, or wrap-up/closing comments.
- Assign a boundary at the moment the transcript shifts from describing what will be done (Preparation) into concrete manipulation steps (Construction), and again when it shifts from core construction to decoration/closure (Finishing).

### GENERAL NORMALIZATION RULES (apply in addition to the above):
- Merge synonyms/variants into one segment label; keep the existing labels as the canonical form when applicable.
- Use concise, unambiguous phrasing; avoid brand-specific or overly narrow wording unless essential to task fidelity.
- Only add a new segment label if the transcript contains a segment that is not covered by any existing segment label.

### PROCEDURE
1) Segment the transcript temporally following the segmentation guidelines.
2) For each segment:
    - Try to map it to an existing segment label.
    - If no existing segment label fits, propose a new segment label following the guidelines.
3) For every segment label in the final list (existing or new):
    - Provide 1-2 representative examples.
    - Each example must include:
        - content (the exact minimal excerpt that would be labeled as the segment label)
        - context (around 10-20 words surrounding the content and the content itself)
    - If a segment label is not evidenced in the given transcript, reuse one example from the existing list if available.

### GOAL
Return an updated list of segment labels for temporal segmentation of the tutorial based on Components (including existing and any new ones needed to cover the given transcript), each with 1-2 concrete examples grounded in the given transcript (or reused from the existing labels).

### GUIDELINES FOR SEGMENTATION:
- If the line talks about the finished product, decoration of the whole hat, or showing/presenting the hat, label as Hat.
- If the line describes folding sheets, turning over flaps, or arranging layers, label as Fold/Flap.
- If the line gives measurements or instructions about making cuts, slits, trimming edges, or multi-layer cutting, label as Slit/Cut.
- If the line concerns surface treatments, base layers, towels, tape, cardboard or paint-preparation, label as Surface/Layer.
- When multiple objects are mentioned, choose the one that is the primary object of the instruction or explanation.

### GENERAL NORMALIZATION RULES (apply in addition to the above):
- Merge synonyms/variants into one segment label; keep the existing labels as the canonical form when applicable.
- Use concise, unambiguous phrasing; avoid brand-specific or overly narrow wording unless essential to task fidelity.
- Only add a new segment label if the transcript contains a segment that is not covered by any existing segment label.

### PROCEDURE
1) Segment the transcript temporally following the segmentation guidelines.
2) For each segment:
    - Try to map it to an existing segment label.
    - If no existing segment label fits, propose a new segment label following the guidelines.
3) For every segment label in the final list (existing or new):
    - Provide 1-2 representative examples.
    - Each example must include:
        - content (the exact minimal excerpt that would be labeled as the segment label)
        - context (around 10-20 words surrounding the content and the content itself)
    - If a segment label is not evidenced in the given transcript, reuse one example from the existing list if available.

### OUTPUT
Return a list of segment labels. Each segment label should have the following fields:
- id: id of the segment label
- label: short text less than 2-3 words
- definition: elaboration of what the segment label means
- examples: 1-2 short representative content and context that would be labeled as the segment label

NOTES
- Ground everything in the provided inputs; no external knowledge or speculation.
- Do not create duplicate or overlapping segment labels.
- Keep examples short and specific; avoid paraphrasing for the 'content' field.

Return an updated list of segment labels for temporal segmentation of the tutorial based on Components (including existing and any new ones needed to cover the given transcript), each with 1-2 concrete examples grounded in the given transcript (or reused from the existing labels).

### GUIDELINES FOR SEGMENTATION:
- If the line talks about the finished product, decoration of the whole hat, or showing/presenting the hat, label as Hat.
- If the line describes folding sheets, turning over flaps, or arranging layers, label as Fold/Flap.
- If the line gives measurements or instructions about making cuts, slits, trimming edges, or multi-layer cutting, label as Slit/Cut.
- If the line concerns surface treatments, base layers, towels, tape, cardboard or paint-preparation, label as Surface/Layer.
- When multiple objects are mentioned, choose the one that is the primary object of the instruction or explanation.

### GENERAL NORMALIZATION RULES (apply in addition to the above):
- Merge synonyms/variants into one segment label; keep the existing labels as the canonical form when applicable.
- Use concise, unambiguous phrasing; avoid brand-specific or overly narrow wording unless essential to task fidelity.
- Only add a new segment label if the transcript contains a segment that is not covered by any existing segment label.

### PROCEDURE
1) Segment the transcript temporally following the segmentation guidelines.
2) For each segment:
    - Try to map it to an existing segment label.
    - If no existing segment label fits, propose a new segment label following the guidelines.
3) For every segment label in the final list (existing or new):
    - Provide 1-2 representative examples.
    - Each example must include:
        - content (the exact minimal excerpt that would be labeled as the segment label)
        - context (around 10-20 words surrounding the content and the content itself)
    - If a segment label is not evidenced in the given transcript, reuse one example from the existing list if available.

### GOAL
Return an updated list of segment labels for temporal segmentation of the tutorial based on Components (including existing and any new ones needed to cover the given transcript), each with 1-2 concrete examples grounded in the given transcript (or reused from the existing labels).

### GUIDELINES FOR SEGMENTATION:
- If the line talks about the finished product, decoration of the whole hat, or showing/presenting the hat, label as Hat.
- If the line describes folding sheets, turning over flaps, or arranging layers, label as Fold/Flap.
- If the line gives measurements or instructions about making cuts, slits, trimming edges, or multi-layer cutting, label as Slit/Cut.
- If the line concerns surface treatments, base layers, towels, tape, cardboard or paint-preparation, label as Surface/Layer.
- When multiple objects are mentioned, choose the one that is the primary object of the instruction or explanation.

### GENERAL NORMALIZATION RULES (apply in addition to the above):
- Merge synonyms/variants into one segment label; keep the existing labels as the canonical form when applicable.
- Use concise, unambiguous phrasing; avoid brand-specific or overly narrow wording unless essential to task fidelity.
- Only add a new segment label if the transcript contains a segment that is not covered by any existing segment label.

### PROCEDURE
1) Segment the transcript temporally following the segmentation guidelines.
2) For each segment:
    - Try to map it to an existing segment label.
    - If no existing segment label fits, propose a new segment label following the guidelines.
3) For every segment label in the final list (existing or new):
    - Provide 1-2 representative examples.
    - Each example must include:
        - content (the exact minimal excerpt that would be labeled as the segment label)
        - context (around 10-20 words surrounding the content and the content itself)
    - If a segment label is not evidenced in the given transcript, reuse one example from the existing list if available.

### OUTPUT
Return a list of segment labels. Each segment label should have the following fields:
- id: id of the segment label
- label: short text less than 2-3 words
- definition: elaboration of what the segment label means
- examples: 1-2 short representative content and context that would be labeled as the segment label

NOTES
- Ground everything in the provided inputs; no external knowledge or speculation.
- Do not create duplicate or overlapping segment labels.
- Keep examples short and specific; avoid paraphrasing for the 'content' field.

### GOAL
Return an updated list of segment labels for temporal segmentation of the tutorial based on Components (including existing and any new ones needed to cover the given transcript), each with 1-2 concrete examples grounded in the given transcript (or reused from the existing labels).

### GUIDELINES FOR SEGMENTATION:
- If the line talks about the finished product, decoration of the whole hat, or showing/presenting the hat, label as Hat.
- If the line describes folding sheets, turning over flaps, or arranging layers, label as Fold/Flap.
- If the line gives measurements or instructions about making cuts, slits, trimming edges, or multi-layer cutting, label as Slit/Cut.
- If the line concerns surface treatments, base layers, towels, tape, cardboard or paint-preparation, label as Surface/Layer.
- When multiple objects are mentioned, choose the one that is the primary object of the instruction or explanation.

### GENERAL NORMALIZATION RULES (apply in addition to the above):
- Merge synonyms/variants into one segment label; keep the existing labels as the canonical form when applicable.
- Use concise, unambiguous phrasing; avoid brand-specific or overly narrow wording unless essential to task fidelity.
- Only add a new segment label if the transcript contains a segment that is not covered by any existing segment label.

### PROCEDURE
1) Segment the transcript temporally following the segmentation guidelines.
2) For each segment:
    - Try to map it to an existing segment label.
    - If no existing segment label fits, propose a new segment label following the guidelines.
3) For every segment label in the final list (existing or new):
    - Provide 1-2 representative examples.
    - Each example must include:
        - content (the exact minimal excerpt that would be labeled as the segment label)
        - context (around 10-20 words surrounding the content and the content itself)
    - If a segment label is not evidenced in the given transcript, reuse one example from the existing list if available.

### OUTPUT
Return a list of segment labels. Each segment label should have the following fields:
- id: id of the segment label
- label: short text less than 2-3 words
- definition: elaboration of what the segment label means
- examples: 1-2 short representative content and context that would be labeled as the segment label

NOTES
- Ground everything in the provided inputs; no external knowledge or speculation.
- Do not create duplicate or overlapping segment labels.
- Keep examples short and specific; avoid paraphrasing for the 'content' field.

[2 - 5] tutorial on how to make a paper hat so
[5 - 7] the first step is you want to draw three
[7 - 10] shapes that look like this now the first
[10 - 13] shape you draw is gonna have a curve
[13 - 16] right there and then the second one is

[25 - 27] the edge once you have this drawing out

[31 - 32] you're gonna have three of these and
[32 - 35] you're gonna take one of them put them
[35 - 37] on a white piece of paper and trace
[37 - 39] around because what you're doing is
[39 - 41] you're you're making two of each shape
[41 - 43] and so you're making sure that each one
[43 - 45] is the same size as the one before
[45 - 47] because if it's not the hats not gonna
[47 - 54] fit together correctly and once you have
[54 - 56] all those traced what you're gonna do is
[56 - 58] take some scissors and you're gonna cut
[58 - 63] each one out this is the time to color
[63 - 66] them and if you want to once you have

[67 - 69] you're gonna take one of them and you're

[71 - 73] edge these represent the seams of the
[73 - 76] Hat and if you want to you can also do a
[76 - 79] dotted line for these instead but you
[79 - 82] can do it however you want and you're
[82 - 88] gonna do that for every single one

[90 - 92] largest ones the slant is going down on
[92 - 94] that side and going up on that one it's
[94 - 98] almost like a mirror image once you have
[98 - 100] them all drawn on what you're gonna do

[103 - 105] it's those two take a piece of tape tape
[105 - 107] on the back and then you're gonna put
[107 - 109] together you are now starting to put the
[109 - 115] Hat together take another piece of tape
[115 - 117] and put it on the back and put them

[119 - 122] each one just make sure that you don't

[124 - 126] you're done sometimes it doesn't fit

[179 - 181] this are going kind of in the mirror

### GOAL
Return an updated list of segment labels for temporal segmentation of the tutorial based on Components (including existing and any new ones needed to cover the given transcript), each with 1-2 concrete examples grounded in the given transcript (or reused from the existing labels).

### GUIDELINES FOR SEGMENTATION:
- If the line talks about the finished product, decoration of the whole hat, or showing/presenting the hat, label as Hat.
- If the line describes folding sheets, turning over flaps, or arranging layers, label as Fold/Flap.
- If the line gives measurements or instructions about making cuts, slits, trimming edges, or multi-layer cutting, label as Slit/Cut.
- If the line concerns surface treatments, base layers, towels, tape, cardboard or paint-preparation, label as Surface/Layer.
- When multiple objects are mentioned, choose the one that is the primary object of the instruction or explanation.

### GENERAL NORMALIZATION RULES (apply in addition to the above):
- Merge synonyms/variants into one segment label; keep the existing labels as the canonical form when applicable.
- Use concise, unambiguous phrasing; avoid brand-specific or overly narrow wording unless essential to task fidelity.
- Only add a new segment label if the transcript contains a segment that is not covered by any existing segment label.

### PROCEDURE
1) Segment the transcript temporally following the segmentation guidelines.
2) For each segment:
    - Try to map it to an existing segment label.
    - If no existing segment label fits, propose a new segment label following the guidelines.
3) For every segment label in the final list (existing or new):
    - Provide 1-2 representative examples.
    - Each example must include:
        - content (the exact minimal excerpt that would be labeled as the segment label)
        - context (around 10-20 words surrounding the content and the content itself)
    - If a segment label is not evidenced in the given transcript, reuse one example from the existing list if available.

### OUTPUT
Return a list of segment labels. Each segment label should have the following fields:
- id: id of the segment label
- label: short text less than 2-3 words
- definition: elaboration of what the segment label means
- examples: 1-2 short representative content and context that would be labeled as the segment label

NOTES
- Ground everything in the provided inputs; no external knowledge or speculation.
- Do not create duplicate or overlapping segment labels.
- Keep examples short and specific; avoid paraphrasing for the 'content' field.

### GOAL
Return an updated list of segment labels for temporal segmentation of the tutorial based on Components (including existing and any new ones needed to cover the given transcript), each with 1-2 concrete examples grounded in the given transcript (or reused from the existing labels).

### GUIDELINES FOR SEGMENTATION:
- If the line talks about the finished product, decoration of the whole hat, or showing/presenting the hat, label as Hat.
- If the line describes folding sheets, turning over flaps, or arranging layers, label as Fold/Flap.
- If the line gives measurements or instructions about making cuts, slits, trimming edges, or multi-layer cutting, label as Slit/Cut.
- If the line concerns surface treatments, base layers, towels, tape, cardboard or paint-preparation, label as Surface/Layer.
- When multiple objects are mentioned, choose the one that is the primary object of the instruction or explanation.

### GENERAL NORMALIZATION RULES (apply in addition to the above):
- Merge synonyms/variants into one segment label; keep the existing labels as the canonical form when applicable.
- Use concise, unambiguous phrasing; avoid brand-specific or overly narrow wording unless essential to task fidelity.
- Only add a new segment label if the transcript contains a segment that is not covered by any existing segment label.

### PROCEDURE
1) Segment the transcript temporally following the segmentation guidelines.
2) For each segment:
    - Try to map it to an existing segment label.
    - If no existing segment label fits, propose a new segment label following the guidelines.
3) For every segment label in the final list (existing or new):
    - Provide 1-2 representative examples.
    - Each example must include:
        - content (the exact minimal excerpt that would be labeled as the segment label)
        - context (around 10-20 words surrounding the content and the content itself)
    - If a segment label is not evidenced in the given transcript, reuse one example from the existing list if available.

### OUTPUT
Return a list of segment labels. Each segment label should have the following fields:
- id: id of the segment label
- label: short text less than 2-3 words
- definition: elaboration of what the segment label means
- examples: 1-2 short representative content and context that would be labeled as the segment label

NOTES
- Ground everything in the provided inputs; no external knowledge or speculation.
- Do not create duplicate or overlapping segment labels.
- Keep examples short and specific; avoid paraphrasing for the 'content' field.

### GOAL
Return an updated list of segment labels for temporal segmentation of the tutorial based on Components (including existing and any new ones needed to cover the given transcript), each with 1-2 concrete examples grounded in the given transcript (or reused from the existing labels).

### GUIDELINES FOR SEGMENTATION:
- If the line talks about the finished product, decoration of the whole hat, or showing/presenting the hat, label as Hat.
- If the line describes folding sheets, turning over flaps, or arranging layers, label as Fold/Flap.
- If the line gives measurements or instructions about making cuts, slits, trimming edges, or multi-layer cutting, label as Slit/Cut.
- If the line concerns surface treatments, base layers, towels, tape, cardboard or paint-preparation, label as Surface/Layer.
- When multiple objects are mentioned, choose the one that is the primary object of the instruction or explanation.

### GENERAL NORMALIZATION RULES (apply in addition to the above):
- Merge synonyms/variants into one segment label; keep the existing labels as the canonical form when applicable.
- Use concise, unambiguous phrasing; avoid brand-specific or overly narrow wording unless essential to task fidelity.
- Only add a new segment label if the transcript contains a segment that is not covered by any existing segment label.

### PROCEDURE
1) Segment the transcript temporally following the segmentation guidelines.
2) For each segment:
    - Try to map it to an existing segment label.
    - If no existing segment label fits, propose a new segment label following the guidelines.
3) For every segment label in the final list (existing or new):
    - Provide 1-2 representative examples.
    - Each example must include:
        - content (the exact minimal excerpt that would be labeled as the segment label)
        - context (around 10-20 words surrounding the content and the content itself)
    - If a segment label is not evidenced in the given transcript, reuse one example from the existing list if available.

### OUTPUT
Return a list of segment labels. Each segment label should have the following fields:
- id: id of the segment label
- label: short text less than 2-3 words
- definition: elaboration of what the segment label means
- examples: 1-2 short representative content and context that would be labeled as the segment label

NOTES
- Ground everything in the provided inputs; no external knowledge or speculation.
- Do not create duplicate or overlapping segment labels.
- Keep examples short and specific; avoid paraphrasing for the 'content' field.

Return an updated list of segment labels for temporal segmentation of the tutorial based on Components (including existing and any new ones needed to cover the given transcript), each with 1-2 concrete examples grounded in the given transcript (or reused from the existing labels).

### GUIDELINES FOR SEGMENTATION:
- If the line talks about the finished product, decoration of the whole hat, or showing/presenting the hat, label as Hat.
- If the line describes folding sheets, turning over flaps, or arranging layers, label as Fold/Flap.
- If the line gives measurements or instructions about making cuts, slits, trimming edges, or multi-layer cutting, label as Slit/Cut.
- If the line concerns surface treatments, base layers, towels, tape, cardboard or paint-preparation, label as Surface/Layer.
- When multiple objects are mentioned, choose the one that is the primary object of the instruction or explanation.

### GENERAL NORMALIZATION RULES (apply in addition to the above):
- Merge synonyms/variants into one segment label; keep the existing labels as the canonical form when applicable.
- Use concise, unambiguous phrasing; avoid brand-specific or overly narrow wording unless essential to task fidelity.
- Only add a new segment label if the transcript contains a segment that is not covered by any existing segment label.

### PROCEDURE
1) Segment the transcript temporally following the segmentation guidelines.
2) For each segment:
    - Try to map it to an existing segment label.
    - If no existing segment label fits, propose a new segment label following the guidelines.
3) For every segment label in the final list (existing or new):
    - Provide 1-2 representative examples.
    - Each example must include:
        - content (the exact minimal excerpt that would be labeled as the segment label)
        - context (around 10-20 words surrounding the content and the content itself)
    - If a segment label is not evidenced in the given transcript, reuse one example from the existing list if available.

### OUTPUT
Return a list of segment labels. Each segment label should have the following fields:
- id: id of the segment label
- label: short text less than 2-3 words
- definition: elaboration of what the segment label means
- examples: 1-2 short representative content and context that would be labeled as the segment label

- Ground everything in the provided inputs; no external knowledge or speculation.
- Do not create duplicate or overlapping segment labels.
- Keep examples short and specific; avoid paraphrasing for the 'content' field.

### GOAL
Return an updated list of segment labels for temporal segmentation of the tutorial based on Components (including existing and any new ones needed to cover the given transcript), each with 1-2 concrete examples grounded in the given transcript (or reused from the existing labels).

### GUIDELINES FOR SEGMENTATION:
- If the line talks about the finished product, decoration of the whole hat, or showing/presenting the hat, label as Hat.
- If the line describes folding sheets, turning over flaps, or arranging layers, label as Fold/Flap.
- If the line gives measurements or instructions about making cuts, slits, trimming edges, or multi-layer cutting, label as Slit/Cut.
- If the line concerns surface treatments, base layers, towels, tape, cardboard or paint-preparation, label as Surface/Layer.
- When multiple objects are mentioned, choose the one that is the primary object of the instruction or explanation.

### GENERAL NORMALIZATION RULES (apply in addition to the above):
- Merge synonyms/variants into one segment label; keep the existing labels as the canonical form when applicable.
- Use concise, unambiguous phrasing; avoid brand-specific or overly narrow wording unless essential to task fidelity.
- Only add a new segment label if the transcript contains a segment that is not covered by any existing segment label.

### PROCEDURE
1) Segment the transcript temporally following the segmentation guidelines.
2) For each segment:
    - Try to map it to an existing segment label.
    - If no existing segment label fits, propose a new segment label following the guidelines.
3) For every segment label in the final list (existing or new):
    - Provide 1-2 representative examples.
    - Each example must include:
        - content (the exact minimal excerpt that would be labeled as the segment label)
        - context (around 10-20 words surrounding the content and the content itself)
    - If a segment label is not evidenced in the given transcript, reuse one example from the existing list if available.

### OUTPUT
Return a list of segment labels. Each segment label should have the following fields:
- id: id of the segment label
- label: short text less than 2-3 words
- definition: elaboration of what the segment label means
- examples: 1-2 short representative content and context that would be labeled as the segment label

NOTES
- Ground everything in the provided inputs; no external knowledge or speculation.
- Do not create duplicate or overlapping segment labels.
- Keep examples short and specific; avoid paraphrasing for the 'content' field.

### GOAL
Return an updated list of segment labels for temporal segmentation of the tutorial based on Components (including existing and any new ones needed to cover the given transcript), each with 1-2 concrete examples grounded in the given transcript (or reused from the existing labels).

### GUIDELINES FOR SEGMENTATION:
- If the line talks about the finished product, decoration of the whole hat, or showing/presenting the hat, label as Hat.
- If the line describes folding sheets, turning over flaps, or arranging layers, label as Fold/Flap.
- If the line gives measurements or instructions about making cuts, slits, trimming edges, or multi-layer cutting, label as Slit/Cut.
- If the line concerns surface treatments, base layers, towels, tape, cardboard or paint-preparation, label as Surface/Layer.
- When multiple objects are mentioned, choose the one that is the primary object of the instruction or explanation.

### GENERAL NORMALIZATION RULES (apply in addition to the above):
- Merge synonyms/variants into one segment label; keep the existing labels as the canonical form when applicable.
- Use concise, unambiguous phrasing; avoid brand-specific or overly narrow wording unless essential to task fidelity.
- Only add a new segment label if the transcript contains a segment that is not covered by any existing segment label.

### PROCEDURE
1) Segment the transcript temporally following the segmentation guidelines.
2) For each segment:
    - Try to map it to an existing segment label.
    - If no existing segment label fits, propose a new segment label following the guidelines.
3) For every segment label in the final list (existing or new):
    - Provide 1-2 representative examples.
    - Each example must include:
        - content (the exact minimal excerpt that would be labeled as the segment label)
        - context (around 10-20 words surrounding the content and the content itself)
    - If a segment label is not evidenced in the given transcript, reuse one example from the existing list if available.

### OUTPUT
Return a list of segment labels. Each segment label should have the following fields:
- id: id of the segment label
- label: short text less than 2-3 words
- definition: elaboration of what the segment label means
- examples: 1-2 short representative content and context that would be labeled as the segment label

NOTES
- Ground everything in the provided inputs; no external knowledge or speculation.
- Do not create duplicate or overlapping segment labels.
- Keep examples short and specific; avoid paraphrasing for the 'content' field.

### GUIDELINES FOR SEGMENTATION:
- If the line talks about the finished product, decoration of the whole hat, or showing/presenting the hat, label as Hat.
- If the line describes folding sheets, turning over flaps, or arranging layers, label as Fold/Flap.
- If the line gives measurements or instructions about making cuts, slits, trimming edges, or multi-layer cutting, label as Slit/Cut.
- If the line concerns surface treatments, base layers, towels, tape, cardboard or paint-preparation, label as Surface/Layer.
- When multiple objects are mentioned, choose the one that is the primary object of the instruction or explanation.

### GENERAL NORMALIZATION RULES (apply in addition to the above):
- Merge synonyms/variants into one segment label; keep the existing labels as the canonical form when applicable.
- Use concise, unambiguous phrasing; avoid brand-specific or overly narrow wording unless essential to task fidelity.
- Only add a new segment label if the transcript contains a segment that is not covered by any existing segment label.

1) Segment the transcript temporally following the segmentation guidelines.
2) For each segment:

    - If a segment label is not evidenced in the given transcript, reuse one example from the existing list if available.

### GUIDELINES FOR SEGMENTATION:
- Label as Plan when the speaker states future intent, assigns tasks, or schedules actions (non-action-oriented planning).
- Label as Measure when the speaker provides measurements, sizes, or explicit approximations (numbers, 'about', inches/cm).
- Label as Manipulate when the speaker gives hands-on physical instructions (fold, flip, tuck, punch).
- Label as Treat when the content is about surface treatment (paint, brush, drying, base layers).

### GOAL
Return an updated list of segment labels for temporal segmentation of the tutorial based on Actions (including existing and any new ones needed to cover the given transcript), each with 1-2 concrete examples grounded in the given transcript (or reused from the existing labels).

### GUIDELINES FOR SEGMENTATION:
- Label as Plan when the speaker states future intent, assigns tasks, or schedules actions (non-action-oriented planning).
- Label as Measure when the speaker provides measurements, sizes, or explicit approximations (numbers, 'about', inches/cm).
- Label as Manipulate when the speaker gives hands-on physical instructions (fold, flip, tuck, punch).
- Label as Treat when the content is about surface treatment (paint, brush, drying, base layers).
- Label as Attach when the content is about joining methods or fastening (glue, sew, staple, tape).
- If multiple verbs are present, choose the verb that represents the primary instructional intent of the utterance.

### GENERAL NORMALIZATION RULES (apply in addition to the above):
- Merge synonyms/variants into one segment label; keep the existing labels as the canonical form when applicable.
- Use concise, unambiguous phrasing; avoid brand-specific or overly narrow wording unless essential to task fidelity.
- Only add a new segment label if the transcript contains a segment that is not covered by any existing segment label.

### PROCEDURE
1) Segment the transcript temporally following the segmentation guidelines.
2) For each segment:
    - Try to map it to an existing segment label.
    - If no existing segment label fits, propose a new segment label following the guidelines.
3) For every segment label in the final list (existing or new):
    - Provide 1-2 representative examples.
    - Each example must include:
        - content (the exact minimal excerpt that would be labeled as the segment label)
        - context (around 10-20 words surrounding the content and the content itself)
    - If a segment label is not evidenced in the given transcript, reuse one example from the existing list if available.

### OUTPUT
Return a list of segment labels. Each segment label should have the following fields:
- id: id of the segment label
- label: short text less than 2-3 words
- definition: elaboration of what the segment label means
- examples: 1-2 short representative content and context that would be labeled as the segment label

NOTES
- Ground everything in the provided inputs; no external knowledge or speculation.
- Do not create duplicate or overlapping segment labels.
- Keep examples short and specific; avoid paraphrasing for the 'content' field.
RESPONSE: {

### GUIDELINES FOR SEGMENTATION:
- Label as Plan when the speaker states future intent, assigns tasks, or schedules actions (non-action-oriented planning).
- Label as Measure when the speaker provides measurements, sizes, or explicit approximations (numbers, 'about', inches/cm).
- Label as Manipulate when the speaker gives hands-on physical instructions (fold, flip, tuck, punch).
- Label as Treat when the content is about surface treatment (paint, brush, drying, base layers).
- Label as Attach when the content is about joining methods or fastening (glue, sew, staple, tape).
- If multiple verbs are present, choose the verb that represents the primary instructional intent of the utterance.

### GENERAL NORMALIZATION RULES (apply in addition to the above):
- Merge synonyms/variants into one segment label; keep the existing labels as the canonical form when applicable.
- Use concise, unambiguous phrasing; avoid brand-specific or overly narrow wording unless essential to task fidelity.
- Only add a new segment label if the transcript contains a segment that is not covered by any existing segment label.

### PROCEDURE
1) Segment the transcript temporally following the segmentation guidelines.
2) For each segment:
    - Try to map it to an existing segment label.
    - If no existing segment label fits, propose a new segment label following the guidelines.
3) For every segment label in the final list (existing or new):
    - Provide 1-2 representative examples.
    - Each example must include:
        - content (the exact minimal excerpt that would be labeled as the segment label)
        - context (around 10-20 words surrounding the content and the content itself)
    - If a segment label is not evidenced in the given transcript, reuse one example from the existing list if available.

### GOAL
Return an updated list of segment labels for temporal segmentation of the tutorial based on Actions (including existing and any new ones needed to cover the given transcript), each with 1-2 concrete examples grounded in the given transcript (or reused from the existing labels).

### GUIDELINES FOR SEGMENTATION:
- Label as Plan when the speaker states future intent, assigns tasks, or schedules actions (non-action-oriented planning).
- Label as Measure when the speaker provides measurements, sizes, or explicit approximations (numbers, 'about', inches/cm).
- Label as Manipulate when the speaker gives hands-on physical instructions (fold, flip, tuck, punch).
- Label as Treat when the content is about surface treatment (paint, brush, drying, base layers).
- Label as Attach when the content is about joining methods or fastening (glue, sew, staple, tape).
- If multiple verbs are present, choose the verb that represents the primary instructional intent of the utterance.

### GENERAL NORMALIZATION RULES (apply in addition to the above):
- Merge synonyms/variants into one segment label; keep the existing labels as the canonical form when applicable.
- Use concise, unambiguous phrasing; avoid brand-specific or overly narrow wording unless essential to task fidelity.
- Only add a new segment label if the transcript contains a segment that is not covered by any existing segment label.

### PROCEDURE
1) Segment the transcript temporally following the segmentation guidelines.
2) For each segment:
    - Try to map it to an existing segment label.
    - If no existing segment label fits, propose a new segment label following the guidelines.
3) For every segment label in the final list (existing or new):
    - Provide 1-2 representative examples.
    - Each example must include:
        - content (the exact minimal excerpt that would be labeled as the segment label)
        - context (around 10-20 words surrounding the content and the content itself)
    - If a segment label is not evidenced in the given transcript, reuse one example from the existing list if available.

### OUTPUT
Return a list of segment labels. Each segment label should have the following fields:
- id: id of the segment label
- label: short text less than 2-3 words
- definition: elaboration of what the segment label means
- examples: 1-2 short representative content and context that would be labeled as the segment label

NOTES
- Ground everything in the provided inputs; no external knowledge or speculation.
- Do not create duplicate or overlapping segment labels.
- Keep examples short and specific; avoid paraphrasing for the 'content' field.
RESPONSE: {
