### GOAL
Return an updated list of segment labels for temporal segmentation of the tutorial based on Purposes (including existing and any new ones needed to cover the given transcript), each with 1-2 concrete examples grounded in the given transcript (or reused from the existing labels).

### GUIDELINES FOR SEGMENTATION:
- Label as General when the instruction is neutral and aimed at any viewer without audience-specific references.
- Label as Party when the content addresses making multiple hats, personalization for events, or group activities.
- Label as Personal when the speaker offers subjective comments, anecdotes, or future-intent remarks about themselves.
- Label as Aesthetic when the content focuses on visual effects, styling, or decorative choices.
- Label as Practical when the content gives functional advice (making things durable, hiding print, improving structure).
- Choose the label that best captures the stated reason or intended audience for the instruction; default to General if no intent is specified.

### GENERAL NORMALIZATION RULES (apply in addition to the above):
- Merge synonyms/variants into one segment label; keep the existing labels as the canonical form when applicable.
- Use concise, unambiguous phrasing; avoid brand-specific or overly narrow wording unless essential to task fidelity.
- Only add a new segment label if the transcript contains a segment that is not covered by any existing segment label.

### PROCEDURE
1) Segment the transcript temporally following the segmentation guidelines.
2) For each segment:
    - Try to map it to an existing segment label.
    - If no existing segment label fits, propose a new segment label following the guidelines.
3) For every segment label in the final list (existing or new):
    - Provide 1-2 representative examples.
    - Each example must include:
        - content (the exact minimal excerpt that would be labeled as the segment label)
        - context (around 10-20 words surrounding the content and the content itself)
    - If a segment label is not evidenced in the given transcript, reuse one example from the existing list if available.

### OUTPUT
Return a list of segment labels. Each segment label should have the following fields:
- id: id of the segment label
- label: short text less than 2-3 words
- definition: elaboration of what the segment label means
- examples: 1-2 short representative content and context that would be labeled as the segment label

NOTES
- Ground everything in the provided inputs; no external knowledge or speculation.
- Do not create duplicate or overlapping segment labels.
- Keep examples short and specific; avoid paraphrasing for the 'content' field.

### GOAL
Return an updated list of segment labels for temporal segmentation of the tutorial based on Purposes (including existing and any new ones needed to cover the given transcript), each with 1-2 concrete examples grounded in the given transcript (or reused from the existing labels).

### GUIDELINES FOR SEGMENTATION:
- Label as General when the instruction is neutral and aimed at any viewer without audience-specific references.
- Label as Party when the content addresses making multiple hats, personalization for events, or group activities.
- Label as Personal when the speaker offers subjective comments, anecdotes, or future-intent remarks about themselves.
- Label as Aesthetic when the content focuses on visual effects, styling, or decorative choices.
- Label as Practical when the content gives functional advice (making things durable, hiding print, improving structure).
- Choose the label that best captures the stated reason or intended audience for the instruction; default to General if no intent is specified.

### GENERAL NORMALIZATION RULES (apply in addition to the above):
- Merge synonyms/variants into one segment label; keep the existing labels as the canonical form when applicable.
- Use concise, unambiguous phrasing; avoid brand-specific or overly narrow wording unless essential to task fidelity.
- Only add a new segment label if the transcript contains a segment that is not covered by any existing segment label.

### PROCEDURE
1) Segment the transcript temporally following the segmentation guidelines.
2) For each segment:
    - Try to map it to an existing segment label.
    - If no existing segment label fits, propose a new segment label following the guidelines.
3) For every segment label in the final list (existing or new):
    - Provide 1-2 representative examples.
    - Each example must include:
        - content (the exact minimal excerpt that would be labeled as the segment label)
        - context (around 10-20 words surrounding the content and the content itself)
    - If a segment label is not evidenced in the given transcript, reuse one example from the existing list if available.

### OUTPUT
Return a list of segment labels. Each segment label should have the following fields:
- id: id of the segment label
- label: short text less than 2-3 words
- definition: elaboration of what the segment label means
- examples: 1-2 short representative content and context that would be labeled as the segment label

NOTES
- Ground everything in the provided inputs; no external knowledge or speculation.
- Do not create duplicate or overlapping segment labels.
- Keep examples short and specific; avoid paraphrasing for the 'content' field.

### GOAL
Return an updated list of segment labels for temporal segmentation of the tutorial based on Purposes (including existing and any new ones needed to cover the given transcript), each with 1-2 concrete examples grounded in the given transcript (or reused from the existing labels).

### GUIDELINES FOR SEGMENTATION:
- Label as General when the instruction is neutral and aimed at any viewer without audience-specific references.
- Label as Party when the content addresses making multiple hats, personalization for events, or group activities.
- Label as Personal when the speaker offers subjective comments, anecdotes, or future-intent remarks about themselves.
- Label as Aesthetic when the content focuses on visual effects, styling, or decorative choices.
- Label as Practical when the content gives functional advice (making things durable, hiding print, improving structure).
- Choose the label that best captures the stated reason or intended audience for the instruction; default to General if no intent is specified.

### GENERAL NORMALIZATION RULES (apply in addition to the above):
- Merge synonyms/variants into one segment label; keep the existing labels as the canonical form when applicable.
- Use concise, unambiguous phrasing; avoid brand-specific or overly narrow wording unless essential to task fidelity.
- Only add a new segment label if the transcript contains a segment that is not covered by any existing segment label.

### PROCEDURE
1) Segment the transcript temporally following the segmentation guidelines.
2) For each segment:
    - Try to map it to an existing segment label.
    - If no existing segment label fits, propose a new segment label following the guidelines.
3) For every segment label in the final list (existing or new):
    - Provide 1-2 representative examples.
    - Each example must include:
        - content (the exact minimal excerpt that would be labeled as the segment label)
        - context (around 10-20 words surrounding the content and the content itself)
    - If a segment label is not evidenced in the given transcript, reuse one example from the existing list if available.

### OUTPUT
Return a list of segment labels. Each segment label should have the following fields:
- id: id of the segment label
- label: short text less than 2-3 words
- definition: elaboration of what the segment label means
- examples: 1-2 short representative content and context that would be labeled as the segment label

NOTES
- Ground everything in the provided inputs; no external knowledge or speculation.
- Do not create duplicate or overlapping segment labels.
- Keep examples short and specific; avoid paraphrasing for the 'content' field.

### GOAL
Return an updated list of segment labels for temporal segmentation of the tutorial based on Purposes (including existing and any new ones needed to cover the given transcript), each with 1-2 concrete examples grounded in the given transcript (or reused from the existing labels).

### GUIDELINES FOR SEGMENTATION:
- Label as General when the instruction is neutral and aimed at any viewer without audience-specific references.
- Label as Party when the content addresses making multiple hats, personalization for events, or group activities.
- Label as Personal when the speaker offers subjective comments, anecdotes, or future-intent remarks about themselves.
- Label as Aesthetic when the content focuses on visual effects, styling, or decorative choices.
- Label as Practical when the content gives functional advice (making things durable, hiding print, improving structure).
- Choose the label that best captures the stated reason or intended audience for the instruction; default to General if no intent is specified.

### GENERAL NORMALIZATION RULES (apply in addition to the above):
- Merge synonyms/variants into one segment label; keep the existing labels as the canonical form when applicable.
- Use concise, unambiguous phrasing; avoid brand-specific or overly narrow wording unless essential to task fidelity.
- Only add a new segment label if the transcript contains a segment that is not covered by any existing segment label.

### PROCEDURE
1) Segment the transcript temporally following the segmentation guidelines.
2) For each segment:
    - Try to map it to an existing segment label.
    - If no existing segment label fits, propose a new segment label following the guidelines.
3) For every segment label in the final list (existing or new):
    - Provide 1-2 representative examples.
    - Each example must include:
        - content (the exact minimal excerpt that would be labeled as the segment label)
        - context (around 10-20 words surrounding the content and the content itself)
    - If a segment label is not evidenced in the given transcript, reuse one example from the existing list if available.

### OUTPUT
Return a list of segment labels. Each segment label should have the following fields:
- id: id of the segment label
- label: short text less than 2-3 words
- definition: elaboration of what the segment label means
- examples: 1-2 short representative content and context that would be labeled as the segment label

NOTES
- Ground everything in the provided inputs; no external knowledge or speculation.
- Do not create duplicate or overlapping segment labels.
- Keep examples short and specific; avoid paraphrasing for the 'content' field.

### GOAL
Return an updated list of segment labels for temporal segmentation of the tutorial based on Purposes (including existing and any new ones needed to cover the given transcript), each with 1-2 concrete examples grounded in the given transcript (or reused from the existing labels).

### GUIDELINES FOR SEGMENTATION:
- Label as General when the instruction is neutral and aimed at any viewer without audience-specific references.
- Label as Party when the content addresses making multiple hats, personalization for events, or group activities.
- Label as Personal when the speaker offers subjective comments, anecdotes, or future-intent remarks about themselves.
- Label as Aesthetic when the content focuses on visual effects, styling, or decorative choices.
- Label as Practical when the content gives functional advice (making things durable, hiding print, improving structure).
- Choose the label that best captures the stated reason or intended audience for the instruction; default to General if no intent is specified.

### GENERAL NORMALIZATION RULES (apply in addition to the above):
- Merge synonyms/variants into one segment label; keep the existing labels as the canonical form when applicable.
- Use concise, unambiguous phrasing; avoid brand-specific or overly narrow wording unless essential to task fidelity.
- Only add a new segment label if the transcript contains a segment that is not covered by any existing segment label.

### PROCEDURE
1) Segment the transcript temporally following the segmentation guidelines.
2) For each segment:
    - Try to map it to an existing segment label.
    - If no existing segment label fits, propose a new segment label following the guidelines.
3) For every segment label in the final list (existing or new):
    - Provide 1-2 representative examples.
    - Each example must include:
        - content (the exact minimal excerpt that would be labeled as the segment label)
        - context (around 10-20 words surrounding the content and the content itself)
    - If a segment label is not evidenced in the given transcript, reuse one example from the existing list if available.

### GOAL
Return an updated list of segment labels for temporal segmentation of the tutorial based on Purposes (including existing and any new ones needed to cover the given transcript), each with 1-2 concrete examples grounded in the given transcript (or reused from the existing labels).

### GUIDELINES FOR SEGMENTATION:
- Label as General when the instruction is neutral and aimed at any viewer without audience-specific references.
- Label as Party when the content addresses making multiple hats, personalization for events, or group activities.
- Label as Personal when the speaker offers subjective comments, anecdotes, or future-intent remarks about themselves.
- Label as Aesthetic when the content focuses on visual effects, styling, or decorative choices.
- Label as Practical when the content gives functional advice (making things durable, hiding print, improving structure).
- Choose the label that best captures the stated reason or intended audience for the instruction; default to General if no intent is specified.

### GENERAL NORMALIZATION RULES (apply in addition to the above):
- Merge synonyms/variants into one segment label; keep the existing labels as the canonical form when applicable.
- Use concise, unambiguous phrasing; avoid brand-specific or overly narrow wording unless essential to task fidelity.
- Only add a new segment label if the transcript contains a segment that is not covered by any existing segment label.

### PROCEDURE
1) Segment the transcript temporally following the segmentation guidelines.
2) For each segment:
    - Try to map it to an existing segment label.
    - If no existing segment label fits, propose a new segment label following the guidelines.
3) For every segment label in the final list (existing or new):
    - Provide 1-2 representative examples.
    - Each example must include:
        - content (the exact minimal excerpt that would be labeled as the segment label)
        - context (around 10-20 words surrounding the content and the content itself)
    - If a segment label is not evidenced in the given transcript, reuse one example from the existing list if available.

### OUTPUT
Return a list of segment labels. Each segment label should have the following fields:
- id: id of the segment label
- label: short text less than 2-3 words
- definition: elaboration of what the segment label means
- examples: 1-2 short representative content and context that would be labeled as the segment label

NOTES
- Ground everything in the provided inputs; no external knowledge or speculation.
- Do not create duplicate or overlapping segment labels.
- Keep examples short and specific; avoid paraphrasing for the 'content' field.

### GOAL
Return an updated list of segment labels for temporal segmentation of the tutorial based on Purposes (including existing and any new ones needed to cover the given transcript), each with 1-2 concrete examples grounded in the given transcript (or reused from the existing labels).

### GUIDELINES FOR SEGMENTATION:
- Label as General when the instruction is neutral and aimed at any viewer without audience-specific references.
- Label as Party when the content addresses making multiple hats, personalization for events, or group activities.
- Label as Personal when the speaker offers subjective comments, anecdotes, or future-intent remarks about themselves.
- Label as Aesthetic when the content focuses on visual effects, styling, or decorative choices.
- Label as Practical when the content gives functional advice (making things durable, hiding print, improving structure).
- Choose the label that best captures the stated reason or intended audience for the instruction; default to General if no intent is specified.

### GENERAL NORMALIZATION RULES (apply in addition to the above):
- Merge synonyms/variants into one segment label; keep the existing labels as the canonical form when applicable.
- Use concise, unambiguous phrasing; avoid brand-specific or overly narrow wording unless essential to task fidelity.
- Only add a new segment label if the transcript contains a segment that is not covered by any existing segment label.

### PROCEDURE
1) Segment the transcript temporally following the segmentation guidelines.
2) For each segment:
    - Try to map it to an existing segment label.
    - If no existing segment label fits, propose a new segment label following the guidelines.
3) For every segment label in the final list (existing or new):
    - Provide 1-2 representative examples.
    - Each example must include:
        - content (the exact minimal excerpt that would be labeled as the segment label)
        - context (around 10-20 words surrounding the content and the content itself)
    - If a segment label is not evidenced in the given transcript, reuse one example from the existing list if available.

### OUTPUT
Return a list of segment labels. Each segment label should have the following fields:
- id: id of the segment label
- label: short text less than 2-3 words
- definition: elaboration of what the segment label means
- examples: 1-2 short representative content and context that would be labeled as the segment label

NOTES
- Ground everything in the provided inputs; no external knowledge or speculation.
- Do not create duplicate or overlapping segment labels.
- Keep examples short and specific; avoid paraphrasing for the 'content' field.

### GOAL
Return an updated list of segment labels for temporal segmentation of the tutorial based on Purposes (including existing and any new ones needed to cover the given transcript), each with 1-2 concrete examples grounded in the given transcript (or reused from the existing labels).

### GUIDELINES FOR SEGMENTATION:
- Label as General when the instruction is neutral and aimed at any viewer without audience-specific references.
- Label as Party when the content addresses making multiple hats, personalization for events, or group activities.
- Label as Personal when the speaker offers subjective comments, anecdotes, or future-intent remarks about themselves.
- Label as Aesthetic when the content focuses on visual effects, styling, or decorative choices.
- Label as Practical when the content gives functional advice (making things durable, hiding print, improving structure).
- Choose the label that best captures the stated reason or intended audience for the instruction; default to General if no intent is specified.

### GENERAL NORMALIZATION RULES (apply in addition to the above):
- Merge synonyms/variants into one segment label; keep the existing labels as the canonical form when applicable.
- Use concise, unambiguous phrasing; avoid brand-specific or overly narrow wording unless essential to task fidelity.
- Only add a new segment label if the transcript contains a segment that is not covered by any existing segment label.

### PROCEDURE
1) Segment the transcript temporally following the segmentation guidelines.
2) For each segment:
    - Try to map it to an existing segment label.
    - If no existing segment label fits, propose a new segment label following the guidelines.
3) For every segment label in the final list (existing or new):
    - Provide 1-2 representative examples.
    - Each example must include:
        - content (the exact minimal excerpt that would be labeled as the segment label)
        - context (around 10-20 words surrounding the content and the content itself)
    - If a segment label is not evidenced in the given transcript, reuse one example from the existing list if available.

### OUTPUT
Return a list of segment labels. Each segment label should have the following fields:
- id: id of the segment label
- label: short text less than 2-3 words
- definition: elaboration of what the segment label means
- examples: 1-2 short representative content and context that would be labeled as the segment label

NOTES
- Ground everything in the provided inputs; no external knowledge or speculation.
- Do not create duplicate or overlapping segment labels.
- Keep examples short and specific; avoid paraphrasing for the 'content' field.

### GOAL
Return an updated list of segment labels for temporal segmentation of the tutorial based on Purposes (including existing and any new ones needed to cover the given transcript), each with 1-2 concrete examples grounded in the given transcript (or reused from the existing labels).

### GUIDELINES FOR SEGMENTATION:
- Label as General when the instruction is neutral and aimed at any viewer without audience-specific references.
- Label as Party when the content addresses making multiple hats, personalization for events, or group activities.
- Label as Personal when the speaker offers subjective comments, anecdotes, or future-intent remarks about themselves.
- Label as Aesthetic when the content focuses on visual effects, styling, or decorative choices.
- Label as Practical when the content gives functional advice (making things durable, hiding print, improving structure).
- Choose the label that best captures the stated reason or intended audience for the instruction; default to General if no intent is specified.

### GENERAL NORMALIZATION RULES (apply in addition to the above):
- Merge synonyms/variants into one segment label; keep the existing labels as the canonical form when applicable.
- Use concise, unambiguous phrasing; avoid brand-specific or overly narrow wording unless essential to task fidelity.
- Only add a new segment label if the transcript contains a segment that is not covered by any existing segment label.

### PROCEDURE
1) Segment the transcript temporally following the segmentation guidelines.
2) For each segment:
    - Try to map it to an existing segment label.
    - If no existing segment label fits, propose a new segment label following the guidelines.
3) For every segment label in the final list (existing or new):
    - Provide 1-2 representative examples.
    - Each example must include:
        - content (the exact minimal excerpt that would be labeled as the segment label)
        - context (around 10-20 words surrounding the content and the content itself)
    - If a segment label is not evidenced in the given transcript, reuse one example from the existing list if available.

### OUTPUT
Return a list of segment labels. Each segment label should have the following fields:
- id: id of the segment label
- label: short text less than 2-3 words
- definition: elaboration of what the segment label means
- examples: 1-2 short representative content and context that would be labeled as the segment label

NOTES
- Ground everything in the provided inputs; no external knowledge or speculation.
- Do not create duplicate or overlapping segment labels.
- Keep examples short and specific; avoid paraphrasing for the 'content' field.

- Canonical segment labels (each starts with an ID in square brackets, e.g., "[S1] ..."):
[S1] Preparation
Definition: Planning and gathering materials, sizing and orienting participants before hands-on making begins.
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
	- Content 1: show you to make a top hat of any size
	- Context 1: you can use the technique I'm going to show you to make a top hat of any size I
	- Content 2: used a cardboard tube but you can use
	- Context 2: show you to make a top hat of any size I used a cardboard tube but you can use construction
```
[S2] Construction
Definition: Active building steps: cutting, drawing templates, folding, gluing, assembling and shaping the hat.
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
	- Content 1: I started by drawing around the cardboard tube at the bottom
	- Context 1: any material that is stiff enough now I started by drawing around the cardboard tube at the bottom then I
	- Content 2: I made a big X like this and I cut on those lines
	- Context 2: and in the middle I just made a big X I'll show you I made a big X like this and I cut on those lines
```
[S3] Finishing
Definition: Final touches, decorating, drying, presentation, or closing remarks after the core construction is complete.
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
	- Content 1: i added stars and glitter
	- Context 1: and I put those on before I glued the bad don't and i added stars and glitter you may not want to
	- Content 2: thanks for watching remember always be kind
	- Context 2: it sure as you can make it any way you want now thanks for watching remember always be kind and please click the
```
- Pieces of information (each starts with an ID in square brackets, e.g., "[p12] ..."):
[1] Greeting: guys today I'm going to be showing you how to make a paper hat.
[2] Overview Goal: The video will show how to make a paper hat.
[3] Suggestion: Before following the video, consider watching the whole video first.
[4] Advice: Use a bigger piece of paper than the one shown for a larger hat.
[5] Explanation Effect: Using a small piece of paper makes a small hat that may not fit on the head.
[6] Transition Bridge: So let's get started.
[7] Instruction: Hold the paper and make sure the crease is good.
[8] Instruction: Ensure the paper is creased well by pressing the fold firmly.
[9] Instruction: Turn the paper to the crease side so the crease is at the bottom.
[10] Instruction: Fold the bottom up to the crease.
[11] Instruction: Hold the paper steady while making a good crease.
[12] Description Status: One corner will have a little space after folding.
[13] Supplementary Tip: A small gap or space in the corner does not matter.
[14] Description Status: The folded paper should look like the displayed example.
[15] Instruction Subgoal: Prepare the body part of the hat for the next fold.
[16] Instruction: Take the first flap only and do not take both flaps together.
[17] Instruction: Lift and fold the selected flap so it looks like the demonstrated shape.
[18] Instruction: Flip the paper over to the other side after folding the flap.
[19] Supplementary Tip: You can use staples to keep parts of the hat together.
[20] Warning: Do not staple in the middle if you want the hat to open properly.
[21] Description Status: The maker reiterated that the hat may be small with the used paper size.
[22] Supplementary Tip: Use a larger piece of paper to make a hat bigger.
[23] Instruction: To make a Robin Hood style hat, fold one side over to the left.
[24] Instruction: Fold the other side the same way to create the Robin Hood hat shape.
[25] Conclusion Outcome: The final folded shape should resemble the demonstrated Robin Hood style hat.
[26] Closing: Please subscribe to this channel and goodbye.
[27] Miscellaneous Side Note: The video is about making paper hats.

If no segment label clearly apply, assign the empty string "".

- If multiple segment labels seem plausible, pick the single best segment label that is most specific to the information piece's content.
- Do not use external knowledge. Ground decisions strictly in the provided transcript.

- label_id: id of the segment label or ""

[1] Hi guys welcome back to Origami Twist.
[2] My name is Jenna.
[3] Today's video is meant for people dealing with snow days and bored children as a result of the snow days.
[4] The instructor lives in Australia but is originally from the northeastern United States.
[5] Facebook was full of complaints about many snow days recently.
[6] This project is great for imagination, playing dress-up, and coming up with stories and ideas.
[7] This project helps prevent kids from getting bored.
[8] You do not have to be in a snowy area to do this project.
[9] The project is the classic newspaper paper hat.
[10] You probably already have all the materials necessary to make this project.
[11] All you need is one sheet of newspaper.
[12] If you have a full-size newspaper, fold it in half.
[13] Fold the newspaper in half again until you have a rectangle about the size shown.
[14] Fold one corner in to make a right triangle.
[15] Fold at the middle when making the triangle fold.
[16] Fold the other corner in to make another right triangle.
[17] Fold the second triangle down in the middle.
[18] After folding both corners you will have a long skinny strip along the bottom and two triangles on top.
[19] Fold the bottom flap up onto itself so it meets the bottom of the triangles.
[20] Fold the bottom flap up again.
[21] Turn the paper around and fold the bottom flap up so it meets roughly the bottom of the triangle on that side.
[22] You can estimate where the bottom should meet by looking at the other side.
[23] The folds do not have to be perfect; rough alignment is acceptable.
[24] Fold the rectangle up again so that it matches the other side.
[25] Open the folded paper up to reveal a shape that looks like a captain's hat.
[26] The open hat appears like a captain's hat.
[27] The instructor looked at the screen instead of the camera because she is not used to doing tutorials this way.
[28] The instructor thanks viewers for bearing with her.
[29] The instructor has another couple of videos that work great with this hat; one is called the captain's shirt story that uses the hat as a base.
[30] If viewers are interested in a further fold turning the hat into the captain's shirt story, the instructor will make videos on it if asked.
[31] Viewers should leave requests or comments below if they want the captain's shirt story or other ideas.
[32] Thank you for watching.
[33] Please subscribe if you enjoy paper crafting.
[34] The instructor hopes viewers have a fabulous day and says goodbye.

[5] Today I kept my daughter entertained with a piece of newspaper and a toilet roll.
[6] Today we're going to make a paper hat.
[7] Get a piece of paper.
[8] Orient the paper so the open ends are towards you.
[9] Fold the paper in half.
[10] Make triangle folds in the paper.
[11] Fold the triangles up quite to the center.
[12] Keep the triangle folds nice and even on both sides.
[13] Fold the bottom flap up.
[14] Fold the bottom flap up halfway.
[15] Fold the bottom flap up again.
[16] Make sure the folds are secure ("make sure it's all muscle").
[17] Turn the paper hat over.
[18] Repeat the same folding process on the other side.
[19] You have a pirate hat.
[20] A piece of newspaper and a toilet roll can be used as inexpensive materials for toddler crafts.

- Pieces of information (each starts with an ID in square brackets, e.g., "[p12] ..."):
[1] Crafts are a wonderful source of entertainment for many people.
[2] Knowing how to make paper hats is useful.
[3] Gather supplies: a piece of paper and a measuring device.
[4] Fold the sheet of paper in half.
[5] Measure the folded paper to make sure the halves are even.
[6] Hold the paper with the unfolded side facing up.
[7] Fold one side up partially, leaving some paper unfolded.
[8] Do not fold the side all the way; leave a small section uncreased.
[9] Repeat the same partial fold on the opposite side.
[10] Fold one of the two remaining flaps down across the front.
[11] Press the fold firmly all the way across the paper.
[12] Fold the other flap inward and crease it up.
[13] Measure the hat to ensure that the folds are about right and aligned.
[14] Pull the folded paper open to form a three-dimensional hat shape.
[15] A finished paper hat can alternatively be used as a paper boat.
[16] Fold the side edges inward to help prevent the interior from collapsing.
[17] Adjust the brim to create small lip-like edges on the hat.
[18] The finished product is a paper hat.
[19] Wear the paper hat.

You are performing temporal segmentation of a tutorial based on Stages (i.e., Divide the transcript into ordered temporal steps of the hat-making process. Assign each transcript piece to the stage it primarily describes: Preparation (planning, gathering materials, orientation), Construction (step-by-step physical building and folding), or Finishing (final touches, decoration, drying, closing remarks).).

### INPUTS
- Canonical segment labels (each starts with an ID in square brackets, e.g., "[S1] ..."):
[S1] Preparation
Definition: Planning and gathering materials, sizing and orienting participants before hands-on making begins.
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
	- Content 1: show you to make a top hat of any size
	- Context 1: you can use the technique I'm going to show you to make a top hat of any size I
	- Content 2: used a cardboard tube but you can use
	- Context 2: show you to make a top hat of any size I used a cardboard tube but you can use construction
```
[S2] Construction
Definition: Active building steps: cutting, drawing templates, folding, gluing, assembling and shaping the hat.
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
	- Content 1: I started by drawing around the cardboard tube at the bottom
	- Context 1: any material that is stiff enough now I started by drawing around the cardboard tube at the bottom then I
	- Content 2: I made a big X like this and I cut on those lines
	- Context 2: and in the middle I just made a big X I'll show you I made a big X like this and I cut on those lines
```
[S3] Finishing
Definition: Final touches, decorating, drying, presentation, or closing remarks after the core construction is complete.
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
	- Content 1: i added stars and glitter
	- Context 1: and I put those on before I glued the bad don't and i added stars and glitter you may not want to
	- Content 2: thanks for watching remember always be kind
	- Context 2: it sure as you can make it any way you want now thanks for watching remember always be kind and please click the
```
- Pieces of information (each starts with an ID in square brackets, e.g., "[p12] ..."):
[1] Hi, I'm Jenny Jones.
[2] I am an arts and crafts expert.
[3] I am here today to show you how to make a paper hat.
[4] You can use any paper to make a paper hat.
[5] I recommend using a nice big piece of newspaper or A3 paper.
[6] Use a nice big piece of newspaper or A3 paper.
[7] If you want your hat to fit your head, use a full sheet sized appropriately.
[8] You need one full sheet of newspaper to make a hat that fits your head.
[9] Start with one full sheet of newspaper.
[10] Take the top of the paper.
[11] Fold the top of the paper down.
[12] Make a crease across the folded edge.
[13] Take a ruler.
[14] Measure halfway across the paper.
[15] Draw a line at the halfway mark.
[16] Place your ruler and pencil to the side.
[17] Take the top left-hand corner of the newspaper.
[18] Fold the top left-hand corner down to the center line.
[19] Make a crease along the left fold.
[20] Fold the top right-hand corner down to the center line.
[21] Make a crease along the right fold.
[22] Take the top piece of paper.
[23] Fold the top piece of paper up again.
[24] Make a crease across the folded edge after folding the top piece up.
[25] Turn the newspaper over.
[26] The amount you fold the side bits in determines the size of the hat.
[27] Folding the side bits in determines whether the hat will fit your head.
[28] Fold the side bits in approximately the amount that fits your head.
[29] Fold the other side in by the same amount.
[30] Lastly, fold the other side of the paper up to match and make a crease.
[31] You have a paper hat.
[32] This paper hat is perfect for a pirate party or a sailor party.
[33] And that's how to make a paper hat.

[11] Use two sized bowls, one larger than the other.
[12] Use scissors.
[13] Use a stapler.
[14] Use tape.
[15] Start forming the hat by creating a mold.
[16] Use the bowls as the mold for the hat.
[17] Put the larger bowl underneath the smaller bowl.
[18] Place the bowls underneath the paper with the smaller bowl under the paper and the larger bowl on top right in the center.

[20] Place the larger bowl on top of the paper-centered mold.
[21] Put your hand up and push down the bowl to form the hat shape.
[22] Push down the top to shape the hat.
[23] Spread out the paper around the bowl to form the hat shape.
[24] Fold and cut the paper as needed to shape the hat.
[25] Get the basic hat shape before securing it.
[26] Secure the shaped paper so the hat shape holds.
[27] Lift up the formed hat top after securing the shape.
[28] Put the small bowl back if part of it is still inside to avoid losing the hat shape.
[29] Secure the hat shape using masking tape.
[30] Ask Jillian to hold down the paper and hold the top while taping.
[31] Circle the tape around the hat to secure it.
[32] Press the tape down as you go around the hat.
[33] Measure the hat to see if it fits the wearer's head.
[34] If the hat is a little big, take it in by folding it a little bit.
[35] Fold the hat over a little bit if it is slightly too large.
[36] Make and secure the hat rim in a later step.
[37] Apply a second row of tape for extra security.
[38] Adding a second row of tape makes the hat more secure.
[39] Trim the hat's excess paper edges to reduce the amount of paper to work with.
[40] Trim the excess paper in a circular shape around the hat.
[41] Make the brim of the hat with the kids by folding the edge to create a brim all around the sides.
[42] Fold the paper edge all the way around to form the brim.
[43] Keep folding the brim up while turning the hat to form it evenly.
[44] Press the folded brim down after folding to secure it.
[45] Go around behind the child and staple the brim to secure it.
[46] Staple the hat even if the staples are not perfectly even.
[47] Present the undecorated hat as ready to go after securing the brim.
[48] Finish making the paper hats; the only remaining step is painting them.
[49] Paint the hats to make them colorful.
[50] Paint the hats with the preschool class tomorrow.
[51] Say that painting the hats with the class should be a lot of fun.
[52] Say goodbye and see you tomorrow.

[1] Today I'm going to show you how to make a paper Indian hat out of construction paper.
[2] Make an Indian hat using just a few steps.
[3] Show what materials you need.
[4] You need construction paper.
[5] You need feathers.
[6] You need paint.
[7] You need paintbrushes.
[8] You need a stapler.
[9] You need scissors.
[10] You need glue to assemble the hat.
[11] Cut the construction paper.
[12] Measure head size to determine how big the hat needs to be.
[13] Figure out how much paper you are going to need based on head size.
[14] Cut the construction paper into small strips.
[15] Make the strips small; the strips do not need to be huge.
[16] If the head is larger, prepare two strips.
[17] Use two strips for a larger head.
[18] Put the two strips together.
[19] To join the two strips together, use a stapler.
[20] Staple the strips on one side.
[21] Wrap the stapled strips around the head to check fit.
[22] Adjust the size of the hat by seeing how far the band needs to go when wrapped around the head.
[23] Ensure the hat band is fitted and has the two ends together after adjustment.
[24] After assembling the hat band, add paint decorations.
[25] Paint whatever design you want on the hat.
[26] Paint blue dots around the hat.
[27] Paint a green squiggly line on the hat.
[28] Glue the feathers to the back of the hat.
[29] Add as many feathers as desired.
[30] Attach three feathers as an example.
[31] You now have an Indian hat as a warrior hat.
[32] Enjoy the hat at a Thanksgiving party or any time you want to make a costume hat for fun.

[S1] Preparation
Definition: Planning and gathering materials, sizing and orienting participants before hands-on making begins.
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
	- Content 1: show you to make a top hat of any size
	- Context 1: you can use the technique I'm going to show you to make a top hat of any size I
	- Content 2: used a cardboard tube but you can use
	- Context 2: show you to make a top hat of any size I used a cardboard tube but you can use construction
```
[S2] Construction
Definition: Active building steps: cutting, drawing templates, folding, gluing, assembling and shaping the hat.
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
	- Content 1: I started by drawing around the cardboard tube at the bottom
	- Context 1: any material that is stiff enough now I started by drawing around the cardboard tube at the bottom then I
	- Content 2: I made a big X like this and I cut on those lines
	- Context 2: and in the middle I just made a big X I'll show you I made a big X like this and I cut on those lines
```
[S3] Finishing
Definition: Final touches, decorating, drying, presentation, or closing remarks after the core construction is complete.
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
	- Content 1: i added stars and glitter
	- Context 1: and I put those on before I glued the bad don't and i added stars and glitter you may not want to
	- Content 2: thanks for watching remember always be kind
	- Context 2: it sure as you can make it any way you want now thanks for watching remember always be kind and please click the
```

[12] You can adjust or fold parts outward to change the hat shape or size.
[13] Make this paper hat for a kid's party.
[14] Please like and share if you enjoyed watching.
[15] Subscribe.

[4] This is what a finished themed paper hat looks like.
[5] I will demonstrate the paper hat folding step by step.
[6] You can use any type of paper you want to make the hat.
[7] You can use newspaper as the paper for the hat.
[8] The first thing you need to do is make sure the paper is completely flat on the edges.
[9] Flatten the paper so the edges are especially even on the side that will become the front of the hat.
[10] Avoid having the paper bumpy because bumps interfere with folding.
[11] Make sure the paper is very flat on this side so the hat will fold correctly.
[12] Fold the paper in half vertically.
[13] Fold the paper in half again.
[14] Fold the paper like this (demonstration of the half fold).
[15] Make sure the folded edge is perfectly aligned and not off the edge.
[16] Adjust the fold so the edges are exactly even.
[17] Press down on the fold to flatten it.
[18] Ensure the paper flutters down evenly after folding.
[19] Press the crease firmly to remove the rest of the air and secure the fold.
[20] Unfold the paper to reveal the crease made for the next step.
[21] Fold the paper back out to create a reference crease.
[22] The crease gives us a center line for the paper.
[23] Fold the top corners of the paper down toward the center crease.
[24] Make sure each corner meets the middle so the corner is right on target.
[25] Align the top corner exactly at the middle of the paper.
[26] Ensure the top folds are even so the hat looks symmetrical.
[27] Fold both top corners down as much as possible toward the center crease.
[28] Fold the paper so that the top corners touch the center crease.
[29] The fold should meet the center crease in the middle of the paper.
[30] Fold the right side corner to the middle crease.
[31] Fold the right side straight to the middle so it connects cleanly to the center.
[32] Make sure the folded corner is connected and flush with the middle crease.
[33] Flatten the folded sections down firmly.
[34] Fold up only the bottom part of the paper once.
[35] Leave a bottom flap at the base of the folded triangle.
[36] Fold the bottom flap up to the base of the triangle.
[37] Flatten the bottom flap down firmly after folding it up.
[38] Make sure the triangular flaps remain folded down and secure.
[39] Fold one side of the bottom flap over so the hat has a folded edge on that side.
[40] Ensure the folded side is perfectly flat.
[41] Repeat the same folding on the opposite side so both sides match exactly.
[42] Fold the other side in half to mirror the first side's folds.
[43] Bring the other side over and fold it the same way to keep symmetry.
[44] Fold the side straight and make sure it is aligned.
[45] Fold the edge again to secure the alignment.
[46] Make sure the new fold is in line with the other folded edge.
[47] Open the hat up by unfolding the bottom slightly so it forms the hat shape.
[48] Open the hat fully so it takes on the proper hat form.
[49] You should now have a basic paper hat formed.
[50] Optionally, curl the brim of the paper hat inward to change it into a pirate-style hat.
[51] Quickly curl the edges to alter the hat shape.
[52] You can turn the paper hat into a pirate hat by curling the brim inward.
[53] Decorate or stick anything onto the hat to customize it.
[54] Personalize the hat any way you want.
[55] If you enjoyed this video and want more videos like this, please like the video.
[56] If you enjoyed this video and want more videos like this, please subscribe.
[57] I'll see you in the next video.
[58] Right place (closing remark).

MESSAGES: ROLE: system

You are a helpful assistant who can understand and analyze tutorial videos about How to Make a Paper Hat.
ROLE: user

You are performing temporal segmentation of a tutorial based on Stages (i.e., Divide the transcript into ordered temporal steps of the hat-making process. Assign each transcript piece to the stage it primarily describes: Preparation (planning, gathering materials, orientation), Construction (step-by-step physical building and folding), or Finishing (final touches, decoration, drying, closing remarks).).

### INPUTS
- Canonical segment labels (each starts with an ID in square brackets, e.g., "[S1] ..."):
[S1] Preparation
Definition: Planning and gathering materials, sizing and orienting participants before hands-on making begins.
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
	- Content 1: show you to make a top hat of any size
	- Context 1: you can use the technique I'm going to show you to make a top hat of any size I
	- Content 2: used a cardboard tube but you can use
	- Context 2: show you to make a top hat of any size I used a cardboard tube but you can use construction
```
[S2] Construction
Definition: Active building steps: cutting, drawing templates, folding, gluing, assembling and shaping the hat.
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
	- Content 1: I started by drawing around the cardboard tube at the bottom
	- Context 1: any material that is stiff enough now I started by drawing around the cardboard tube at the bottom then I
	- Content 2: I made a big X like this and I cut on those lines
	- Context 2: and in the middle I just made a big X I'll show you I made a big X like this and I cut on those lines
```
[S3] Finishing
Definition: Final touches, decorating, drying, presentation, or closing remarks after the core construction is complete.
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
	- Content 1: i added stars and glitter
	- Context 1: and I put those on before I glued the bad don't and i added stars and glitter you may not want to
	- Content 2: thanks for watching remember always be kind
	- Context 2: it sure as you can make it any way you want now thanks for watching remember always be kind and please click the
```
- Pieces of information (each starts with an ID in square brackets, e.g., "[p12] ..."):
[1] Today we're going to make hats.
[2] I took off my hat.
[3] Take off your hat.
[4] We're going to make hats out of newspaper.
[5] All you need is newspaper.
[6] Take one sheet of newspaper.
[7] Use one sheet while you're there.
[8] Do not read the newspaper; make hats instead.
[9] We are making hats, not reading.
[10] A newspaper is usually already folded, so leave the newspaper folded.
[11] Leave the newspaper folded just like this.
[12] Fold the newspaper in half hamburger style (wider fold).
[13] Make a crease right down the middle of the folded newspaper.
[14] The crease does not have to be perfect.
[15] You should have a visible crease in the middle.
[16] Fold the top two corners down where the fold is.
[17] Fold the corners down so they meet along the center crease.
[18] Fold both top corners on the same side.
[19] The folded paper should look like a triangular-front shape with an open bottom.
[20] The bottom of the folded triangular shape should be kind of open.
[21] Locate the bottom edge of the folded triangles where there appear to be two sheets of paper.
[22] Fold up the first (outer) sheet of paper along the bottom edge.
[23] Pull the outer sheet up all the way so it looks like a thick crease (hot dog style).
[24] The folded-up side should look like the triangles' base folded up.
[25] Flip the paper over to the back side.
[26] Size the hat by folding the side panels inward to fit the head.
[27] Fold the sides in more for a smaller head.
[28] Fold the sides in a couple of inches for a smaller head.
[29] Fold the sides in just a little bit for a bigger head.
[30] Fold the other side up and in the same way and make a nice crease.
[31] Hold the folded sides so they do not flap out.
[32] The back of the hat should look like folded sides held together.
[33] On the front side, fold the bottom edge up.
[34] Fold the front bottom edge up so the front and back folds are on opposite sides.
[35] Leave a little space in the middle as the base where the head goes.
[36] Pop out the folded hat slightly so it fits around the head.
[37] The completed hat should fit the head when adjusted properly.
[38] You can orient the hat whichever way you want (front facing either direction).
[39] You can put small things in the little room in the brim.
[40] Decorate the hat by having things hang out of the brim.
[41] Decorate your hats.
[42] Add decorations to make funny hats.
[43] Stick a googly eye on the hat.
[44] Add multiple googly eyes to the hat.
[45] After adding googly eyes, the hat will have eyes.
[46] That is our crafty mid-cross craft.
[47] Alright by the way that is our crafty mid cross craft.

- piece_id: id of the piece
- label_id: id of the segment label or ""

[1] Hi, my name is Laura.
[2] I am an artist.
[3] I am going to show you how to make a three-sided paper hat.
[4] You will need a sheet of paper.
[5] Use an eight-and-a-half by eleven inch sheet of paper for this demonstration.
[6] Using an eight-and-a-half by eleven inch sheet of paper will make a small hat.
[7] Use a larger sheet of paper to make a larger hat.
[8] Fold the paper in half lengthwise.
[9] After folding the paper in half lengthwise, use your fingernail to make that fold sharper.
[10] Make sure that the folded side of the paper is away from you.
[11] Make sure that the open edges of the paper are toward you.
[12] Fold the upper right corner toward the middle of the paper.
[13] Fold the upper left corner toward the middle of the paper.
[14] Fold the upper right and left corners so they meet in the middle.
[15] Make a temporary fold after bringing the corners to the middle.
[16] Sharpen the temporary fold with your fingernail on both sides.
[17] After sharpening the folds you will have flaps left facing towards you.
[18] Fold one flap up on one side of the hat.
[19] Press the folded flap down with your fingernail.
[20] Flip the hat over.
[21] Fold the other flap up on the other side of the hat.
[22] You will have one, two, three corners on your hat.
[23] Put the three-sided paper hat on your head.
[24] Thank you for watching how to make a three-sided paper hat.

Examples (Contents and Context): ```
	- Content 1: I started by drawing around the cardboard tube at the bottom
	- Context 1: any material that is stiff enough now I started by drawing around the cardboard tube at the bottom then I
	- Content 2: I made a big X like this and I cut on those lines
	- Context 2: and in the middle I just made a big X I'll show you I made a big X like this and I cut on those lines
```
[S3] Finishing
Definition: Final touches, decorating, drying, presentation, or closing remarks after the core construction is complete.
Examples (Contents and Context): ```
	- Content 1: i added stars and glitter
	- Context 1: and I put those on before I glued the bad don't and i added stars and glitter you may not want to
	- Content 2: thanks for watching remember always be kind
	- Context 2: it sure as you can make it any way you want now thanks for watching remember always be kind and please click the
```
- Pieces of information (each starts with an ID in square brackets, e.g., "[p12] ..."):
[1] Hey everybody this is gonna be a tutorial on how to make a paper hat.
[2] Draw three shapes as the first step.
[3] Make the first drawn shape with a curve on one side.
[4] Make the second drawn shape a little less curved and with a small slant going up.
[5] Make the second drawn shape with a small slit.
[6] Make the third drawn shape the smallest and least curved on the edge.
[7] Cut out each drawn shape after drawing them.
[8] You will have three cut-out pieces after cutting the shapes.
[9] Place one cut-out shape on a white piece of paper and trace around it.
[10] Make two copies of each shape by tracing because you need two of each shape.
[11] Ensure each traced shape is the same size as the original shape.
[12] If the shapes are not the same size the hat will not fit together correctly.
[13] Cut out all the traced shapes with scissors after tracing them.
[14] Color the cut-out shapes if desired at this stage.
[15] Draw lines around the edge of one cut-out to represent seams.
[16] Use dotted lines instead of solid lines for seam marks if preferred.
[17] Draw seam lines for every cut-out piece.
[18] For the two largest pieces make sure the slant on one goes down on one side and up on the other side like a mirror image.
[19] Arrange and check the drawn pieces to confirm the slants are mirror images before assembly.
[20] Take the two matching pieces, put tape on the back, and put them together.
[21] Start assembling the hat by taping pieces together at the back.
[22] Add another piece of tape to the back and attach the next pieces together.
[23] Repeat taping for each piece during assembly.
[24] Do not tape too close to the top because the hat may not fit together correctly.
[25] Leave enough room when taping so adjustments can be made if needed.
[26] Attach one of the smallest pieces to one side of the hat.
[27] Attach the other smallest piece to the opposite side of the hat.
[28] Place the smallest pieces symmetrically on each side because symmetry is required.
[29] Follow the specified order when attaching pieces to ensure the hat assembles correctly.
[30] Attach the remaining small piece to the other side.
[31] For the two largest pieces ensure the slants go in opposite directions like a mirror image when attaching them.
[32] Be careful when aligning the slants on the largest pieces.
[33] Continue taping on the back and putting pieces together as before for the largest pieces.
[34] Make sure the slants on attached pieces continue to face opposite directions.
[35] Expect the two last pieces to be the most difficult to fit together because the area is crowded when forming the circular shape.
[36] If assembly is difficult, keep taping on the back and press the pieces together to work around tight areas.
[37] A gap at the top of the hat is acceptable.
[38] Do not worry about small leftover pieces of tape during assembly.
[39] If extra tape is sticking out, cut off the extra tape with scissors.
[40] Do not worry about the gap at the top because it will be covered later.
[41] Take thin cardboard to make reinforcement pieces for the hat.
[42] You can use any thin cardboard such as Ritz cracker box cardboard.
[43] Cut about six cardboard tabs for reinforcement, though four tabs are usually sufficient.
[44] Keep extra cardboard tabs as backups in case of mistakes.
[45] Bend the cardboard tabs to make them easier to fit when taping them inside the hat.
[46] Place the cardboard tabs inside the hat and tape around them to reinforce the hat.
[47] Taping around the entire hat makes the hat more sturdy.
[48] Taping around the hat gives the hat a round shape so it won't crumble when worn.
[49] Continue taping around the top and bottom of the hat and ensure the taped parts are secure so they won't fall off.
[50] You may be able to see through the white hat to the cardboard, and that is fine.
[51] If the hat is colored on the inside, you probably will not see through to the cardboard.
[52] Make the brim by placing the hat down and drawing a half-circle shape for the brim.
[53] Draw the brim shape lightly in case you need to erase mistakes.
[54] Once satisfied with the brim shape, darken the outline.
[55] Put the hat on and draw a half-circle around the edges to mark brim placement.
[56] Darken the half-moon brim shape after drawing it.
[57] Cut out the brim with scissors after finalizing the drawing.
[58] Color the brim if desired after cutting it out.
[59] Draw seam lines on the brim with a pencil to represent seams.
[60] Optionally draw dotted lines on the brim instead of solid lines.
[61] Stop drawing seam lines short of the very end of the brim and leave that area blank.
[62] Trace around the paper brim onto cardboard to make a stiff brim piece.
[63] It is acceptable if the cardboard for the brim is a little bit too small but ensure it is not too small.
[64] Cut the traced cardboard brim piece out to stiffen the brim.
[65] Glue the cardboard brim piece with glue.
[66] Attach the paper brim to the glued cardboard brim piece.
[67] Flip the brim over after gluing and check for any writing or marks on the cardboard side.
[68] Trace and cut a piece of paper to cover any writing or marks on the cardboard brim.
[69] Place the cut paper over the writing and press it down to hide the marks.
[70] If the marks are still visible through the paper, repeat the process with another layer until they are not visible.
[71] Ensure the shape used to cover the cardboard matches the shape on the hat before taping the brim.
[72] Tape the brim to the bottom of the hat with several pieces of tape and make sure the brim is straight.
[73] Fill gaps by cutting a rectangular piece of paper and gluing it inside the hat.
[74] Pat the glued rectangular paper down inside the hat so you cannot see through anymore.
[75] Make airholes by drawing six circles on paper, shading the centers, and cutting them out.
[76] Glue the bottom of each cut-out circle and paste them onto the hat where airholes are desired.
[77] Make the very top of the hat by cutting a paper strip and forming it into a circular ring.
[78] If the paper strip is too long, trim it to a suitable length before forming the ring.
[79] Cut out a paper circle and glue the circular ring to the circle to form a top piece.
[80] Use a bit more glue than shown if necessary to secure the top piece.
[81] Glue the completed top piece to the top of the hat.
[82] Add logos to the hat using letters, designs, or printed stickers to make it look more realistic.
[83] Print a sticker online, glue the back, and put it on the brim for a more realistic look.
[84] The paper hat is complete.
[85] Message the instructor with any questions and the instructor will answer.
[86] Post a video response with your hat if you want; the instructor would love to see it.
[87] Good luck.

### GOAL
For each piece, assign exactly one segment label from the provided labels.
If no segment label clearly apply, assign the empty string "".

### MATCHING RULES
- Choose only from the provided segment labels; output the segment label exactly as given.
- If multiple segment labels seem plausible, pick the single best segment label that is most specific to the information piece's content.
- Do not use external knowledge. Ground decisions strictly in the provided transcript.

### OUTPUT

- piece_id: id of the piece
- label_id: id of the segment label or ""
- label: segment label or ""

### NOTES

- Do not drop or merge pieces.

[S1] Preparation

- Pieces of information (each starts with an ID in square brackets, e.g., "[p12] ..."):
[1] Hello and welcome to Tutti Frutti.
[2] My name is Anita.
[3] Show how to make a paper hat.
[4] Make the paper hat for a Christmas cracker.
[5] Use tissue paper, a ruler, a pencil, some glue, and some scissors.
[6] Use a 20 by 30 inch piece of paper.
[7] Fold the 20 by 30 inch piece of paper into four.
[8] Folding the paper into four makes four hats.
[9] Speed up the video.
[10] My head is 24 inches.
[11] Use 24 inches as the measurement for the hats.
[12] State that the head is quite big.
[13] Measure 24 inches along the paper.
[14] Cut just over the 24 inch measurement.
[15] Fold the measured piece into three.
[16] Cut off the top and the bottom of the folded piece.
[17] Cutting off the top and bottom produces four separate hats.
[18] Have four separate hats.
[19] Cut a triangle in the top of the hat.
[20] Cut half a triangle.
[21] Glue the two sides together.
[22] Thank you for watching.
[23] Offer to show how to make the cracker from the hat in another video.
[24] Provide a link in the description to the cracker-making video.
[25] Say goodbye (bye for now).

- Pieces of information (each starts with an ID in square brackets, e.g., "[p12] ..."):
[1] All right, opening remark introducing the project to make a mini paper hat.
[2] The goal is to make a mini paper hat.
[3] Get any size of paper that you would like.
[4] Use a rectangular, palm-sized or hand-sized piece of paper for a small hat.
[5] Fold the paper in half.
[6] Fold the paper in half again.
[7] Make four segments by folding the paper into quarters.
[8] Fold one side but not the other side the same way (create an asymmetrical fold to form segments).
[9] Open the folded paper back up.
[10] Flip the paper into half after opening it up.
[11] Verify that you have eight segments now.
[12] Fold the paper down three folds (one, two, three) sequentially.
[13] Fold the paper up in half.
[14] Repeat folding the remaining four sides in the same way for the rest of the hat.
[15] Fold inwards on the right side (make an inward dish-like fold).
[16] Fold the opposite side inward as well.
[17] Make the same inward fold for the other side of the paper.
[18] Form a hat-like shape by arranging the folded parts into a peaked shape.
[19] Take one folded flap, fold it backward, and tuck it back into the hat structure.
[20] Flip and tuck the other folded flap into place as well.
[21] Cut off excess parts where indicated.
[22] Fold the cut flap to try and fit it into the hat for the same sides.
[23] If there is excess space, adjust the flap placement to make it fit.
[24] Put the folded flap inside the opening (tuck the flap inside the hat).
[25] Repeat tucking the flap on the same side to secure the structure.
[26] Fold and slide the flap parts into place so the hat stays assembled.
[27] Check that the flaps match properly and that the pieces are inside the hat.
[28] Small imperfections on the sides are acceptable and are not an issue.
[29] You have created a mini paper hat.
[30] You can make the hat larger by using bigger paper if you want a bigger hat.
[31] Bigger paper will make a hat that more people can use or display.
[32] Good luck and thanks for watching; closing farewell.
